output: Thank you, Mr. President. I very much welcome the approach we describe in the White Paper, that we get to the bottom of the causes of malnutrition and obesity and the resulting diseases.
Unfortunately, in European food policy, whether we're talking about nutrient profiles, food labeling, or even in some parts of the White Paper, we fall back on a very one-sided approach.
We are trying to solve the problems we have in Europe through product policy.
I believe that it is fundamentally the wrong approach to assume that there are good and bad foods.
Many proposed amendments demonstrate this. It does not exist.
There are only good and bad, or balanced and unbalanced, ways of eating.
This should be our approach.
The causes of poor nutrition are multifaceted.
Trying to solve this by guiding consumers through product labeling, or even by imposing advertising bans or regulations, or by applying different VAT rates, will not achieve our goal.

I believe that everything we do here - and I don't want to get ahead of the labeling regulation debate - should be framed under the heading: What can we do to motivate consumers to think about their eating habits?
In my opinion, a traffic light label that suggests to him that I am now faced with a good or bad product is more an instrument of disempowerment than an instrument of education and enlightenment.
That is why I would like to see a more balanced approach here and the realization that the path through product policy alone will not take us forward. Thank you.
Madam President, Madam Vice-President, dear colleagues, budget control has no new issues.
We are satisfied with the old ones and would also be satisfied with progress on the old topics.
First and foremost, five points: our urgent request for support for Romania and Bulgaria in building the rule of law, the judiciary, and financial control.
We don't want to be where we are today in two years, and that's why this point is very, very important to us.
The second point: The declaration of assurance for the overall budget following the tiered control procedure, incorporating the national audit offices.
It would be great if we could make decisive progress in the last six months that remain to the Commission, or at least agree on a common path.
One becomes modest as a household controller.
The third point would be simplification.
We need to provide more help to the lower administrative levels of the Member States in implementing EU law.
It turns out that they are completely overwhelmed by large parts of EU law, which is why the high error rates occur.
The fourth point: Foreign aid. Here, I would like to address, above all, Kosovo and the question of cooperation with the United Nations.
The Committee on Budgetary Control has been to Kosovo. I would like to announce now that Kosovo will play a certain role in the budget discharge.
I believe that we have fallen far short of the European Union's capabilities so far and that we urgently need to catch up in this area.
The fifth point would be to improve cooperation between member states in combating fraud.
We have homework here, primarily for the members of the Council.
The Parliament will vote on the legal basis, the anti-fraud regulation, in November, and then we will have to consider together how to proceed if we want to achieve better results in this area.
At least that has been our common wish so far.
Mr President, India and Europe need more and better contacts with each other at all levels, especially at the level of so-called ordinary people.
Business travelers, tourists, students, etc. A brief note on this: it also has significance for the Commission's legislative program, which we discussed earlier.
In global air travel, we need good safety regulations, ones that are effective, not just empty symbolic measures.
It would therefore be a sensible, truly necessary measure to finally abolish the nonsensical liquid regulations and come up with something better.
I voted in favour of the resolution because it is a clear call on the Belarusian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for a democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship were not fulfilled with the questionable, indeed fraudulent, parliamentary elections in September.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of the opposition and civil society.

At the same time, we have today called on the Council and the Commission to facilitate and intensify contacts between the peoples and to democratize the country by seriously considering the possibility of a
Consider reducing visa fees for Belarusian citizens when entering the Schengen Area, thereby preventing the increasing isolation of Belarus and its citizens.
First of all, I would like to refute the notion, which I heard just a few minutes ago, that foreigners are flooding the job market, our job market.
Secondly, I would have liked a clearer, more unambiguous report from the Employment Committee.
Trust in the social cohesion of the European Union can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as European primary law.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council, the Commission, the Member States and the European Court of Justice and not be satisfied with merely calling for a balance between fundamental rights and the freedoms of the internal market and freedom of movement.
We are not changing anything with this. Fundamental social rights, like freedom rights, are human rights that must not be restricted by the free movement within the internal market.
It is about defending and improving the European social model, and it is high time to introduce a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU treaties.
It is time to amend the Posting of Workers Directive so that wage and minimum standards requirements cannot be limited to minimum requirements.
Mr President, I would like to join in thanking the rapporteur, Doris Pack, a sentiment that has already been expressed by many of my fellow Members, and quite rightly too.
We have someone with her who, hopefully, doesn't actually shed her heart and soul, but invests a great deal of heart and soul into this space.
I am pleased with her and the colleagues who have also said that there has been some progress, including in the area of police cooperation.
This is important so that actual life on the ground can also function in reasonable ways.

However, I still believe that we must repeatedly remind our interlocutors in Bosnia and Herzegovina that a great deal still needs to be contributed by you, on your part, probably more than is currently being contributed in some areas.
The internal cooperation, the willingness to engage in this internal cooperation within the ethnic groups is something that we must constantly demand.
It's not a case of everyone trying to go their own way.
And also the integration into the regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is important.
Madam President, the distance between the European Union and its citizens must not become as great as it has become.
We need to make sure it is reduced in size.
In this context, the Ombudsman has an important task, especially when and where he does it well.
Above all, it is also about the fact that we must expect the Ombudsman to act with commitment and a sense of proportion.
The point is that we should not raise expectations that are too high for anyone to meet.

However, on the other hand, it is also about ensuring that wherever shortcomings have occurred in the administration of European institutions, these are addressed and, where possible, reasonable solutions are sought that can then reassure and satisfy the citizens.
Experience to date has shown that the Ombudsman takes this task seriously and does a good job of it.
We can hope that this will continue to be the case and thank him and the rapporteur for this report.
Yes.
Dear colleagues, ten years after the realization of monetary union, Europe is in a severe crisis.
Banks are collapsing or are being supported with billions of dollars from the state budget, sales are plummeting, and millions of people are worried about their jobs and their future.
But not only has the market failed, the ruling politics also seem incapable of learning from their mistakes.

We are of the opinion that, even with such interim comments - and we do not wish to make a particular point with them - serious mistakes were made in the construction of the Economic and Monetary Union.
One such mistake is the structural separation of monetary and fiscal policy. You cannot create a common currency without simultaneously harmonizing tax and spending policies, at least in outline.
I think the economic imbalances in the Eurozone have become enormously worse.
What we need now is indeed better coordination of economic and, above all, tax policies.
We need effective measures against tax dumping, tax havens must be closed, and capital flows must finally be controlled again.
We see the second serious mistake in the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact.

Anyone who considers household consolidation to be unavoidable in times like these is clearly living in a different world. There would be nothing more disastrous than responding to this economic crisis with public austerity programs.
The Stability Pact has clearly demonstrated its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
In our opinion, an investment offensive is necessary to renew public infrastructure and improve the situation of the socially disadvantaged in Europe.
We see a third mistake in the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to democratic control and is solely committed to the goal of price stability.

We advocate for democratic control of the European Central Bank and also demand a correction of the ECB's monetary policy mandate, so that in the future, growth and employment must be promoted at least equally with price stability.
The current crisis also offers an opportunity for profound reforms of the European monetary and financial architecture.
This opportunity should not be squandered lightly.
Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, honourable Members. Indeed, the automotive industry is in crisis, and there are many reasons for this.
The financial crisis, in particular, has accelerated the crisis in this sector, and member states are currently working on solutions.
The European automotive industry is a key industry.
And that is why we need European solutions for this key European industry in order to overcome the crisis.
Almost all car companies have European structures.

In order to make necessary investments in environmentally friendly cars, as has been mentioned several times here today, and to implement environmentally friendly and fuel-efficient technologies, car manufacturers need public guarantees or low-interest loans from the European Investment Bank.
But the supplier industry, which is also very important, must not be forgotten in this context.
It is precisely in the supply industry, in small and medium-sized enterprises, where jobs are created and where innovations take place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
In the last plenary session, the Council President made a proposal to protect key industries.
A good proposal, in my opinion. If one consistently follows through on this proposal, it would mean a Volkswagen law for the entire European automotive industry.
and this would certainly be a good instrument.
But this protective instrument is currently being fought against by the European Commission.
And my question to the Commission is: Will the European Commission persist with a lawsuit despite the crisis in the automotive industry, or will it change course in light of the crisis?
Dear Mr President, Mr President of the European Court of Auditors, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, dear colleagues, It has indeed become a tradition to note that,
It is permissible that, in the relationship between expenditure at the European level and administration at the national level, a declaration of assurance cannot be issued once again.

I can recall conversations with the former President of the Court of Auditors, Professor Friedmann, who once told me that, due to the structures in place, it is not at all possible to provide a statement of assurance.
That is why we should start thinking about how this instrument can be brought to life in such a way that the goal of a declaration of assurance can be achieved when it is justified.
And of course, we need to distinguish a few things from each other here.
Firstly, a budget that includes around ninety subsidies is much more susceptible to fraud than a national budget or a regional or municipal budget.

A subsidy budget, which is essentially managed by the member states, who have demanded much more autonomy from us in the new financial period, because the criticism in the last funding period was that too much was centrally controlled.
Of course, this also means that responsibility for the money must be taken on at regional and national levels.
And I just want to briefly touch on a third area of focus.
We must also learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
These are also things that are always thrown together.
I also get annoyed when EU money is used to fund things that aren't absolutely necessary.
But that was not fraud, that was waste.

Therefore, those responsible for the projects, especially in the field of structural policy, have also given the Member States the responsibility to ensure that money is not wasted and that only projects which really generate added value for the region are promoted.
That is why we should consider converting parts of the structural policy into interest-free loans.
If Member States have to repay, they only promote what they really need. Thank you very much.
It is not just me who finds it difficult to agree with the emerging self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to dealing with the financial market crisis.
This is not going to work because if this EU were a functioning democracy, one would first have to ask the question about responsibility and how all of this could have happened.
It is simply not true that all the problems we are facing now are a tsunami and a matter of natural law, but rather they are man-made.
And with all the regulatory zeal that this Union has demonstrated, one wonders why no action was taken when banks began to cross national borders on a significant scale?
Why, despite appropriate warnings, did no action take place when derivatives crept in like this?
I remember well that your Nobel laureate was Josef Stiglitz and he addressed all these points.
There was a silence, there was a taboo.
That is where one must start, because recognizing one's own mistakes is the only key to finding solutions in the future.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, my question is about what you think of Iceland and Hungary introducing the euro as a second currency.
Do you think that could solve the problem of these two countries?
The second question is: Do you believe it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives, which could then be used to strengthen the banks' equity capital?
My third question is, do you not believe that a reduction in value added tax would accordingly support imports, especially from China and India?
Wouldn't it be more sensible to consider tax reductions for our businesses and investment incentives for our employees, and to adjust progressive depreciation accordingly?
The focus is on increasing low-value economic goods by a factor of 10, so that apparent profits are not taxed, the money remains in the businesses, and wages can be paid better.
Madam President, the comprehensive report highlights the numerous human rights violations that occur daily around the world.
This is particularly alarming sixty years after the declaration of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and calls on us to intensify our efforts.
This is also why I would like to advocate for the current Subcommittee on Human Rights to be established as a main committee.
Today we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Anhu Jia, who campaigns for human rights and the environment in China.
However, because he is incarcerated, he was unable to take possession of it in person.
A disgrace for China, and tomorrow there will be a debate here on human rights violations in Russia.
In our relations with these two countries, not only economic interests, but above all human rights, must be given a higher priority.
We demand freedom for Hu Jia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, Commissioner, dear colleagues, As rapporteur for the Anti-Fraud Office, one gains interesting experiences, such as the fact that everyone talks about combating fraud and then no one does anything.
or the experience of Member States calculating their payments to the European Union with a fine-tipped pen, but loosening their purse strings when it comes to spending that money
and even make it easy for fraudsters, for example, by the fact that it still takes on average between six and thirty months for irregularities to be reported to the European Union at all.
The European Parliament disagrees with this.
We want efficient fraud prevention that also includes prevention.
We want the member states to make the fight against fraud a priority and for us to discuss the necessities and challenges together.
We want to see greater interest from national judicial authorities in following up on OLAF investigation results.
In the case of Kromenturen, there can no longer be areas free of legal regulations as has been the case up to now.
We need to equate European money with national money.
We want an independent agency that has the necessary resources and legal basis to fulfill its tasks.
And we want an office that can work smoothly and efficiently with the member states.
Our opinion on the legal basis covers all these points.
We advocate for the further development of this regulation as the core of the anti-fraud office, in collaboration with the Council.
We urge the Council to incorporate our opinion, we urge the Council to begin discussions on the further development of this regulation.
We want to bring OLAF's problems to a solution.
I thank all the factions of the High House for supporting this in a resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and Czech Council Presidencies to take up Parliament's ball and pass it back.
In our proposals, we have also incorporated solutions developed and submitted by the Council working group.
On our part, I can tell you that we are interested in a swift conclusion of this regulation and assure you of our constructive willingness to engage in discussions based on our proposals.
Consolidating all the OLAF legal bases, as the Council has indeed planned, would mean a further considerable loss of time with an uncertain outcome.
Ola will soon be celebrating his tenth birthday.
Consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal basis.
We take the fight against fraud too seriously for that.
That is why we want to implement what is feasible now in cooperation with the Council.
Thank you very much.
Mr President, I would like to take up a point that my Austrian colleague Paul RÃ¼big raised earlier.
We spend less than one percent of European GDP on Europe, and at the same time we demand that the European Union should handle more and more tasks for more and more member states.
This accounting cannot add up. It is therefore truly unbelievable that we have been implementing austerity measures for many years, but these measures are not limited to mere frugality.
It is not about using our funds effectively, but rather about allowing finance ministers to collect money at the end of the year and incorporate it into their domestic budgets.
We would have enough new tasks for which we should spend our money.
We also have tasks that we have not really adequately budgeted for in years.
I believe that the European Union's information funding needs to be significantly increased if we really want to connect European citizens to Europe.
And there are many tasks in the area of student and apprentice exchange that Europe could deploy here.
that democracy is also advancing in the justice sector, a traditionally state-reserved area.
This corresponds to the changed living conditions of people in our Union.
But this point has already been made several times. Integration must not interfere too much with traditionally established structures, especially those that are already functioning well.
Not everything can be lumped together.
Public records and public notaries are structured quite differently in many member states.
In Austria, but not only in our country, the notary's role as a public authority for authenticating documents has a long tradition and enjoys a high level of security and trust.
This should not be jeopardized unnecessarily, just because such professional groups do not exist elsewhere.
Therefore, integration and mutual openness are a good thing, but in moderation.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues, plant protection products have been and remain essential inputs for agriculture.
Farmers need a minimum selection of plant protection products because it is about protecting the native cultural landscape, providing high-quality nutrition, and conserving resources.
We discuss chemicals all too often on a very irrational level.
But in order to get sensible results, we must think and act rationally.

The consequences of the original parliamentary stance would have been disastrous: a broad ban on plant protection products would have led to lower agricultural yields and, ultimately, rising food prices.
Therefore, I am glad that a barely acceptable compromise was found in the trilogue negotiations.
It is commendable that we have maintained the three-zone regulation, albeit with significant exceptions for the member states.

A courageous step towards a consistent internal market solution would look different. In addition to acceptable compromises, we should not pre-empt a final definition of endocrine-active substances, but actually give the EU Commission the four years of time to present a scientifically sound definition.
Otherwise, we would be stretching the precautionary principle at this point.
And finally, I find it regrettable that we did not take the initiative to initiate a follow-up assessment of the agreement that has now been reached. Thank you.
The last time similar opinion polls were conducted during a visit by a head of government or state, the President of this House intervened massively.
At that time, it was about an issue that was important to him personally, namely the Lisbon Treaty.
When the sovereignly elected president of a country speaks today and is massively interrupted and disturbed by the socialist side, the president does not intervene.
Do you know what that is?
This is not democracy, this is arbitrary rule, and I demand that appropriate measures be taken.
Madam President. Children and politics: Rarely do the interests of citizens and politicians diverge so widely.
The issue of children is at the top of the agenda for citizens across Europe.
For politicians, children's interests are a distant concern, as we can see once again here.
I know of no country that has its own Ministry for Children, and there is no dedicated representative for the interests of our youngest citizens in the Commission either.
The issue of children is spread across all parliamentary committees.
That is why I would like to particularly emphasize to the Commission at this point that it is dealing with childcare facilities and the Barcelona objectives today.
In our parliamentary working group Equality of Childhood, we have established the following: Our children live in a very complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here, now, and today is completely uncertain.
A child today can climb all the way to the top of the social ladder or fall all the way to the bottom.
It can remain in its own cultural circle or seek a new one.
They may follow a similar life path to their parents or do exactly the opposite.
One can marry someone of the opposite or the same gender.
All of this was completely different more than fifty years ago, when we were launching unified Europe.
The diversity that distinguishes us Europeans has become a determining factor in the lives of children.
The concept of diversity must therefore be incorporated into the pedagogy of child-care workers and teachers.
This is still far too little taken into account at present.
Europe's childcare facilities and schools are indeed struggling with the challenge of integration.
In matters of integration, we need to press the reset button, back to the beginning.
Let's approach this topic once again completely free of prejudice, in accordance with the motto "Unity through Diversity."

Furthermore, I ask all the Members of the European Parliament who follow me: Do not only advocate for gender mainstreaming, but also fight for children's mainstreaming, especially now during the global financial crisis, because otherwise we will be imposing immeasurable debts on our children.
Thank you, Mr. President. I will keep this very brief.
I am very grateful for the constructive contributions to the debate that I have heard here.

I would just like to send out two final messages. Firstly, I would like to expressly thank the Commissioner for not having fundamentally spoken out against the concept of minimum requirements for the safety net.
This proposal is not a devil's invention, nor is it a bureaucratic monster.
It is a problem-solving tool that we should give a chance.
That's why I would like to take this opportunity to advocate for it once again.
The second thing I want to say, and this is now directed at my British friends, across all parties.
My dear British friends, I do understand Caroline, I do understand your problem.
I can well understand that a country might prioritize energy security over compliance with an air pollutant limit value for a certain period.
I have great understanding for that.
I am also the last person who would not give Her Majesty additional time when it comes to building new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about it.
The problem is, we haven't done exactly that.
This conversation has never taken place over the last four months.
I would like to ask you to be open-minded once again about the outlook in the second reading at this point and to say, "Let's talk about a compromise at this point."
in my view, the completely irrational resistance, which is not justified from a competition policy or environmental policy perspective, to abandoning the fundamental opposition to minimum standards.
I believe that this is the point where a compromise can be reached, which I hope we will ultimately achieve in the second reading.
Incidentally, I do not believe that we should not seek a compromise in a first reading.
This legislation is too complex for that.

I do not want to end this legislative period as rapporteur and leave the next Parliament with legislation in which a legislative text is being discussed that is inconsistent, illogical, and contradictory.
That is why I am asking for support for the compromises when we vote in an hour.
Dear colleagues, the crucial question regarding all the economic stimulus programs currently being developed across Europe is, of course, who ultimately receives the money?
more blank checks are being issued to the banks, even though rapid nationalization would ultimately be much cheaper for the taxpayer.
And are the corporations and high-income earners to be further relieved of their burdens, even though they have been fattened up for years throughout Europe with tax gifts?

The more money is squandered on such purposes, the more foreseeable it becomes that such programs will fail, and the more likely it is that the European economy will continue to sink into a very dangerous downward spiral.

The years-long policy of privatization, deregulation, liberalization - this very policy has increasingly concentrated income among the top ten, and it was this policy that is responsible for the current crisis in which we find ourselves today.
Anyone who believes that they can overcome this crisis by continuing to pursue exactly this policy with minor modifications has simply not understood anything.
The exact opposite of this is needed.
Instead of buying up bad debts from banks, tax money should be used to renovate schools, hospitals, and to restructure the European economy in an environmentally friendly way.

If private companies receive public funds, it must be clear that no tax money is given without guarantees of employment, and especially no tax money without the acquisition of public property rights, so that the state and, above all, the general public can also share in the future profits.
The best economic stimulus program currently available would be a radical redistribution of income and wealth from top to bottom.
The low-wage sector in Europe must be reduced, rather than being continually promoted.
We need higher minimum wages, we need better social benefits in Europe.

And we need taxes that ensure that the millionaires and the beneficiaries of the past financial market party now also bear the immense losses that have been incurred, and not the vast majority of citizens who never benefited from the financial boom in the first place.
I believe that what is socially just is currently also the only sensible approach in economic policy.
And it is the only way to break the devastating crisis dynamics.
Mr. President, in early March, political prisoners Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev were transferred from Chita in Siberia to Moscow to be re-charged on the basis of untenable accusations.
The first public hearing day was scheduled for March 31st.
On the same day, the EU-Russia human rights consultations were supposed to take place.
These important talks have now been postponed by the Russian side indefinitely.
Russia is thus demonstrating very clearly the low priority it places on human rights.
The judiciary continues to be used not only to ensure justice, but also to eliminate regime opponents, and the EU is being duped as a result.
Mr President, thank you very much, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I am particularly grateful to Commissioner Verheugen for once again addressing the issue of the ban on animal testing.

because it reminds me that this is now the third amendment to the cosmetics legislation that I have been able to accompany, the sixth amendment, the seventh amendment, and now the amendment to a regulation.
We have indeed managed to ban animal testing.
We have succeeded in ensuring that consumers know how long a product will last by including a small can with a number inside that indicates how long it is still valid.

I also say this to some of my colleagues, especially to my colleague Reuthofer, who unfortunately couldn't be here at the beginning. Labels are never warnings at any time. If a product is not safe, it should not be on the market, it should not be marketed.
Every product on this European market must be safe and harmless.
But the labeling gives consumers the opportunity to choose.
That is democracy and that is your freedom of choice.
I believe that we have very good legislation.
I have tried to make the process very transparent.
I have tried, as Mrs. Kostet also said, to bring together different opinions.

Because I am concerned that we create legislation that is good for everyone, for consumers in the European Union, for the industry that has to work with this legislation, and ultimately for all those who benefit from it.
To my colleague Schnellhardt, I say once again, yes, DEO works differently for everyone, but the claim that it keeps you sweat-free is still made.
That is why it is important that the statements regarding the depth of my wrinkles around my eyes after a week in Strasbourg are quite realistic and reliable.
I would like to express my thanks once again to the Commissioner, also for the explanations he has provided, to my fellow Members and to my assistant, who has done most of the work.
Thank you very much.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues. The report by our colleague Mr Van Nistelrooij on the Green Paper and the future shape of cohesion policy is certainly one of the most significant reports by the Committee on Regional Development in recent years.
We agree with the basic concept of the Green Paper, which states that territorial cohesion is about promoting the polycentric development of the EU.
to ensure overall sustainable development of the territories with different characteristics and features, while preserving their diversity.
It is correct that in the next planning period, a more comprehensive system of phased assistance will be introduced for transition regions that cross the threshold of seventy-five.
gross domestic product will be exceeded, a framework must be created so that these regions receive a clear status and thus have more security in their development.
And in colleague Kreh's report on the obstacles to the absorption of Structural Funds, the most significant shortcomings faced by applicants are rightly listed.
are eligible for Structural Funds, such as excessive administrative burdens, too many complex regulations, slow and cumbersome centralized administration in the Member States.
And various recommendations are made to the Commission on what effective measures should be taken to remove these obstacles.
I would like to single out and emphasize two such measures.
Firstly, project managers currently have to keep their project documents for a period of ten years, in order to have them on hand for inspections that may be carried out by the Commission.
This is particularly an excessive bureaucratic effort for smaller projects.
It is true that this is now to be reduced to a period of three years. Secondly, the EU Commission's evaluation criteria for innovative projects are causing significant problems.
Innovative projects cannot be evaluated using the same criteria as other projects.
It is simply necessary for something different to happen here.

Madam President, when Europe takes money into its hands and when, above all, the Member States take a lot of money into their hands to help the automotive industry in its crisis situation, it cannot only be about securing the status quo and preventing job losses here, but it is also about a number of other concerns.
The most important ones have been mentioned.
It is about helping people to find employment, and they also need to secure this employment in the long term.
To achieve this, it is necessary that we promote new technologies, innovation, and above all sustainability in the transportation system more strongly than we have done so far.

We should therefore link all our measures to these objectives, so that in a few years we do not have to face the accusation that we should have thought of all this many years ago, and that we would not be in the next and new crisis.
Madam President, it would be kind of you to grant me the extra half a minute that my Green colleague, Mrs Breyer, has just received.
The Commission had put forward a good proposal to update the regulation on novel foods.

Unfortunately, some proposed amendments attempt to supplement this proposal with provisions that are not compatible with the objectives of the regulation or even seek to interfere with existing case law.
The obligation of food business operators to monitor novel foods with a view to animal health and welfare would simply overwhelm traders.
And once again, there is an attempt to undermine the existing GMO laws, namely the demand for special labeling of such novel foods derived from animals that were fed genetically modified feed.
We just heard it.
In principle, anything that affects the GMO legislation should not be included in the Novel Food Regulation.
I say this even though I myself, for example, had submitted a proposal to specifically exclude new plant species from the definition of novel foods.
But it cannot be that interested parties in this House misuse the Novel Food Regulation for campaign purposes.
This appears to be the case with proposed amendments two, sixty, and ninety, for which the Greens have requested a recorded vote.
Who, dear colleagues, do you want to expose in this way?
My group has always been in favor of the consumer's right to know what is in their food.
Why, then, should one not indicate a nano origin in the declaration of ingredients?
And although Amendment two and sixty clumsily attempts to anticipate my report on food labeling, I must tell you that I consider this labeling of novel food to be entirely compatible with my report.

I therefore recommend that my group approve the aforementioned motions and will include references to the part of the Novel Food Regulation dealing with labeling in my report on the Food Labeling Regulation.
This is possible because we have postponed the first reading on food labeling to the next legislative period, against the wishes of the Greens.
But now it is clear to everyone how advantageous this postponement was.
In short, cloning is animal cruelty.
We are against it.
Nevertheless, food products must be included in this regulation accordingly, because otherwise they would no longer function within a legal framework.
Madam President. It is quite simple.
If anyone does not want this man to chair the solemn opening session of the European Parliament, they should support my motion to amend the rules of procedure. Thank you.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. Let me make one thing clear: in the upcoming vote on the report by our colleague Sikerski, the distribution of food to those in need, especially in these economically difficult times, is not up for debate.
That is why I would like to make it clear from the outset that it was not easy to find a common line within our group.
I therefore respect the personal decision of each group colleague to deviate from this and not to agree with the rejection of the report that we have planned.
Why can I not agree with the outcome of the committee vote in this form?
There are a number of reasons for this, which have nothing whatsoever to do with helping those in need in the European Union during these economically difficult times.

On the contrary, the amendments submitted by my colleague Nils Busk on behalf of the ALDE group, but unfortunately found not to be admissible, were intended to place the existing system on a sustainable footing.
Because the current system is an anachronism from the days of agricultural overproduction, which fortunately belong to the past.

Thanks to the successful decoupling of direct payments, intervention stocks have steadily decreased in recent years, so that today up to eighty-five percent of food products must be purchased on the open market.
However, this has fundamentally changed the nature of the program and led to the loss of its agricultural policy dimension.
However, since we are now dealing with a social program, we need to establish an appropriate legal basis for it.
We are hereby sharing the assessment of the Council's legal service, which, instead of Articles seven and thirty of the EEC Treaty on the common agricultural policy, merely states that
considers Article 308 as a legal basis as otherwise it would clearly be an infringement on the national competence of the Member States.
Given the inadmissibility of our amendments, the only solution can be a new draft from the European Commission.
This should continue to adhere to the principle of co-financing, because only on-site can the sense and nonsense of such programs be satisfactorily evaluated in the interests of all.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, we too welcome the European Commission's proposal and this Green Paper in principle.
There is a mass phenomenon, described by the various previous speakers, where relatively small damages occur among a large number of people.
For the individuals affected, the damage is small, but when added up, it is significant.
An instrument is needed to deal with this problem.
In my opinion, it is also right that people think about such things.

I also very much welcome the fact, to keep things positive, that the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has placed a crucial emphasis in its Green Paper on the question of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms.

This is a significant difference compared to the White Paper of the Directorate-General for Competition, which was also discussed here yesterday and has so far completely ignored the possibility of extrajudicial dispute resolution mechanisms.
I think the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has gone further in its Green Paper than its competition colleagues.
However, I also want to make two things very clear, which in my opinion should definitely be understood as critical remarks.
In a few minutes, at twelve o'clock, Parliament will conclude my report on the White Paper of the Directorate-General for Competition.
We will demand from the European Commission, with an overwhelming majority in this House, that a horizontal approach be adopted in dealing with this issue.
It cannot be that we end up with sectoral instruments, one for consumer protection, another for antitrust law, yet another for the capital market, and perhaps even another one for the environment.

Perhaps one more for social affairs, and they all contradict each other; they all interfere with the legal systems of the member states and ultimately lead to a legal and political mess that no practitioner can manage anymore.
We have had such examples many times in the past.
I am only thinking of the debate on the Professional Qualifications Directive, which we later also summarized in one instrument because this fragmentation was no longer tenable.
The Commission should not make the same mistake here.
It should promote the horizontal approach from the outset.
This is the clear stance of the Parliament, and it will become evident in a few months, in a few minutes, right here.

One final point: I am also very pleased that we have reached a consensus that we do not want an American-style litigation industry, with a turnover of 240 billion US dollars per year, where ultimately only lawyers profit and consumers gain nothing from it.
We want genuine rule of law in Europe and to remain true to our traditional systems and our understanding of law.
Dear colleagues, there are many ways to cope with the lasting consequences of the unexpected financial and economic crisis.

This revision package, this legislative measure as part of the European economic stimulus program, is designed as a good response, albeit not entirely sufficient, but it is, first and foremost, a good response to this temporary, albeit exceptionally critical situation.
It also aims, among other things, to promote greater simplification of procedures and greater flexibility in the application of existing ones.
Provisions under the Structural Funds Regulation, as called for, dear colleagues, by the European Parliament on several occasions in recent years.

It is also to be welcomed, and I would like to particularly emphasize this, that a change in Article seven should enable the eligibility of expenditure concerning the Member States and regions of the EU.
to invest structural policy funding in energy efficiency and renewable energy in residential construction, and that these measures should not only be available to low-income households.
The relevant amendment rightly deletes the line on low-income households and instead introduces a ceiling of four of the total ERDF budget for each Member State for such expenditure.
This is just one of the many proposed improvements.
In short, once this overall package is implemented, it will accelerate spending and thus provide additional liquidity for the implementation of necessary measures.
Provisions from Structural Funds, ERDF, ESF and Cohesion Fund resources, and a simplification of the regulations that enable rapid implementation of the programmes.
an effective contribution, although not a sufficient contribution to addressing the current crisis situation.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues. I fundamentally welcome the European Ecolabel.
It is right that we are making a new attempt to further disseminate this Community eco-label.
I also think it's right that we continue to rely on volunteerism in the future.
In the future, the mark will only be successful if there are clear criteria and standards that require the acquisition of this mark.
Here I appeal to the EU Commission to develop reasonable, clear, and understandable criteria.
The incentive concept must be at the forefront.
It would be unfortunate if the establishment of the environmental label fails due to bureaucratic obstacles.
Ultimately, it is the consumer who decides on success or failure, because it is with them that acceptance must be achieved.

Although I personally am very fond of the Blue Angel, which we have in Germany, in the end it should not be a matter of taste, but rather it is important that the consumer is immediately informed about the special properties of a product.
Added value for consumers will only be created if the Member States abandon their own symbols and a uniform symbol is introduced at European level.
A whirlwind of symbols confuses the consumer and does not inform him.
A sign, a statement. That's what we should work on together.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that during this legislative period, we have made significant progress together in the discharge procedure for the European institutions.
However, I regret that it has taken so long, because in principle, we have only now addressed everything that was already evident with the resignation of the Commission in 1999, i.e., ten years ago.

This shows that we still need to improve our working methods and procedures and ensure that the necessary transparency is achieved more quickly when it comes to citizens knowing how their tax money is being used.
I would particularly like to thank my colleague Kazaka, with whom I had the honour of working on the parliamentary discharge for the EPP Group.

I deeply regret this, which is why I quickly took another look to see that a colleague who expresses himself very intensively about various matters of the European Parliament in the press does not participate in the committee discussions, the committee votes, or the plenary debate here.
I want to say this very clearly at this point, so that it is preserved for posterity. We are well aware that there were a number of problems here.

We were and are, and it was the Members of Parliament who are here now, who have ensured over the past five years that the necessary reforms were achieved in a variety of areas in the interests of the Members of Parliament.

A heartfelt thank you to everyone for that. We have done what was necessary, and we have made sure that everything is not only widely reported in the media, but also that people are actually cooperating.
Thank you for the serious cooperation.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the AUDI report - for which I would like to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur - is a real step forward because it includes innovative elements, such as naming and shaming, a milestone in budgetary control.
Targeted criticism instead of blanket accusations.
The fact that the socialist group in particular is now backing down and prefers to sweep the truth under the rug is a scandal and a disservice to our oversight duties.
The credibility of Parliament is at stake, and I appeal to my colleagues not to allow this to happen.
A word about our most troubled children, Romania and Bulgaria.
The Commission's failure in preparing for the accessions is most tangible here.
We have lost a lot of money.

The Commission has long turned a blind eye and has only recently frozen two thousand eight funds, amounting to over one billion euros for Bulgaria and around one hundred and forty-two million euros for Romania.
Freezing money is not a solution to the problems.
The cooperation and verification mechanism, for which the Commission President himself is responsible, is a paper tiger, and the progress reports do not deserve the name.
In this section, the Audi report offers suggestions on how things could be improved.
The EU Commission has misled Parliament about the readiness of these countries to join, and the Commissioner for Enlargement should actually draw consequences from this.
However, our focus is on managing future accessions, which is why this topic remains on the agenda.
Our group will grant discharge to the Commission, but I personally will deny discharge to the Commission.
Unfortunately, the Commission's reform zeal, which could be glimpsed again last year, has already faded.
Stalemate in the fight against fraud, nothing on prevention, more ethics not wanted, etc.
The Commission, and Commissioner Kallas in particular, should be aware of one thing: if the new Commission wants to secure the support of Parliament, it needs to act accordingly.
Mr President, yes, we have a problem with copyright and we have a problem with the remuneration of artists.
That is correct, and we need to take action and do something about it.
But when we take action, it's about really responding to the challenges of the digital age and not flogging dead horses.
I will explain why I came to this word.
The proposal on the table actually only fulfills one promise, and that is the promise to promote the music industry.
When we get to the point of understanding what happens to the artists themselves and their income, and we calculate it through, we also come to
Such low average amounts that it is by no means sufficient for an artist's livelihood, in a way that he can make a living from it.
Moreover, this money does not reach the artists directly.
and the fund is too small to achieve anything.
An artist I discussed this with told me that what's happening here is a redistribution from the living to the dead.
I had to contradict him. It is a redistribution from the artists to the producers, to the music industry, and only to the big ones.
All in all, Commissioner, this proposal is not suitable.
We need to find better ones.
We need to create something like a flat rate, for example.
The suggestions you make regarding the "use it or lose it" clause also remain theoretical rights.
Please let us do something sensible and well-founded, as the artists recommended and requested in our hearing in the Committee on Legal Affairs.
Mr President, I share the rapporteur, Gilles Sabery's, regret that the Commission has not pursued its original plan for an integrated action plan.
There are many good reasons why all parties involved, from local communities to the European Union, are striving to improve urban traffic conditions.
We know that most people in Europe live in cities and that the current traffic conditions are far from optimal.
Therefore, in principle, I agree with the plan and the report by my colleague Mr Savary to draw up corresponding integrated proposals from the Parliament's initiative.
I thank him for his commitment and also for the concrete suggestions.
At the same time, however, I would like to make it very clear that what many fear or believe they must fear will not happen.
No one wants to take away the right of municipalities, local and regional authorities, to shape their own traffic conditions.
From the European side, we merely want to contribute to ensuring that reasonable common rules are followed here, if a municipality, if a city, if a regional entity deems it reasonable.
The principle of subsidiarity is not compromised.
What we want to do here is to protect this principle.
It therefore remains that we strive, in the interest of citizens, to ensure that not when a citizen travels ten, twenty kilometers in Europe
Europe continues to drive, he comes across a traffic-calmed zone that he believes he knows from his home town, and there he finds completely different rules in place.
No one wants to impose city tolls or other regulations on any communities, but if they are actually implemented here, then they should also be made in a recognizable framework for the citizens.
For more than a hundred years, we have agreed on the usefulness of common approaches when it comes to traffic signs.
This should also be the case in the future with this topic.
Mr President, we have been dealing with urban transport in the EU for a long time now.
Why, really?

We are not competent for this. The jurisdiction was originally constructed because about eighty percent of the population live in urban areas, and because of the climate debate, they now want to address the issue.
Fortunately, we were able to reduce the European Commission's ambitions to an action plan for urban transport through our protest.
I thank Commissioner Tajani for his insight.
Subsidere does indeed mean support rather than prescribe, but of course, as an Italian, he knows this better than I do as a German with only a basic knowledge of Latin.
My primary concern is that our report, the report of the Parliament, emphasizes strict adherence to the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.
Legislative measures at the European level are inadmissible for urban traffic.
Supportive measures. That is our task.
A collection of ideas and the promotion of the exchange of best practices makes sense.
Not everyone has to reinvent the wheel.
Our cities need tailor-made solutions, but these can only be developed by the local actors, because they are the ones who know what is necessary.
The municipalities must meet very different situations. They therefore need sufficient room for manoeuvre, also in order to keep inner-city trade vital.
This is important for a city's attractiveness.
It is therefore important not to exclude motorized individual traffic and to focus more on urban logistics.
I would therefore like to see research into urban last-mile delivery promoted.
That relieves a city.
It is also important that demographic change is taken into account.
Our society is becoming older after all.
Mobility needs and housing requirements are changing.
We need a supply of everyday goods close to where people live if we want to reduce traffic, and this is also a challenge for the retail sector.
Anything else would only require a green field.
In conclusion, we do not need an observation point for urban traffic.
Such a position would cost a lot of money and produce a lot of paper that would only be filed away in Brussels. Thank you.
Madam President, I fully support the Commission's goal of establishing a legal framework for the coordinated introduction and use of intelligent transport systems in road traffic.

My years-long personal struggle for the standard introduction of eCall, the electronic emergency call system, makes the urgency clear to me almost every day. But intelligent traffic systems can do much more.
They serve environmental compatibility, efficiency improvement, increased safety, and non-discriminatory competitiveness in road freight and passenger transport.

Furthermore, they support co-modality, among other things by developing interfaces to other modes of transport such as rail, waterways, and air travel, where the integration of intelligent transport systems has already begun.
All of this cannot be achieved by the Member States alone, but only as a Community task.

Intelligent transport systems, based on EU-wide binding fundamental standards and minimum quality regulations, improve the environment for innovation and create planning security, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
I particularly welcome the planned open vehicle-integrated platform for intelligent traffic system services.
The action plan finally includes a schedule for the introduction of individual systems a for road safety such as ESP and eCall b for continuity in traffic management, for example, information on
Avoiding toll fees or parking lot management search traffic? c The use of real-time road, traffic, and travel data will enrich not only professional drivers, but all road users.
The directive sets out detailed requirements for the coordinated, EU-wide introduction of intelligent transport systems and their application in the Member States.
It also ensures the handling of personal data.
But beware: The introduction of intelligent traffic systems incurs high costs, as infrastructures and vehicles must first be equipped with the necessary information and communication technologies.
We still know too little about the willingness and ability of potential users to pay.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we clearly support aid for people with rare diseases.
But Amendment Fifteen is ethically completely unacceptable.
There must never again be a debate in Europe about life worth living and life not worth living.
There should be no political or social pressure in Europe on parents to consciously choose against having a disabled child.
The selection of embryos would be a major ethical breach.
Therefore, this amendment must be rejected, and it is not enough to simply eliminate the word that unfortunately corresponds to fascist language use, "schreichen."
but it would still be a matter of fact that there is a selection of embryos.
And it would be intolerable if this amendment, which speaks of a selection of enembryos, were to become a springboard for a new ethic in Europe.
We must resolutely oppose genetic discrimination.
Therefore, Amendment 15 must be rejected in its entirety. Otherwise, our group would unfortunately also be forced to vote against this report, which is otherwise largely positive.
Mr President, I voted against granting discharge to the Commission in the discharge vote for the first time since I have been a Member of this House and I would like to
I would like to present my reasons. My main concern is the way the European Commission has handled and managed the accession of the two new countries, Romania and Bulgaria.
We are dealing with a multitude of problems in Romania and Bulgaria, with a high level of corruption, with a lot of European money that has disappeared.
The European Commission only began to freeze these funds in the year two thousand and eight.
We lost a lot of money in 2007 and are now dealing with barely any control systems or control systems that only function intermittently.
In Romania, we are dealing with a high rate of corruption and problems with the judiciary.
All of this is to be blamed on the pre-accession process.

My goal is to set an example, to also tell the European Commission that it must proceed differently for future accessions, and to also tell it that, if it has already been observed in other countries, it could certainly be more successful if it so desires.
I would like to call on the Commission to help the two countries establish financial control systems that deserve the name, and to eliminate the systemic weaknesses in these two countries.
otherwise we will have a permanent problem and a permanent cause for concern for all of Europe.

Madam President, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that behind me, in the area of the right-wing radicals, there are people who are not Members of Parliament, and as far as I can see, they are indeed using their voting cards.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I expressly welcome Horst Schnellhard's draft report and thank him for his excellent work.
Following the numerous crises of recent years involving products of animal origin that pose a risk to human and animal health, comprehensive legal regulation is essential.
A revision of the current regulations has become necessary.
We still need to ensure a high level of security.
Although we generally agree with the report, I see some points that make me think.
The regulation has been made less stringent in many respects, thereby slightly relaxing the trade in animal by-products.
Some examples: There is permission to use certain Category 1 materials in pet food.
Category two or three materials can be disposed of more easily under official supervision, regardless of their risk level, if the amount of waste per week is low.
However, the risk of animal by-products of any category is only partly determined by the quantity.
The European Commission will still issue the implementing regulation, and the draft, like the previous one, contains many authorisations for the Commission.

This means that the Commission can make comprehensive and fundamental regulations on the handling of animal by-products through the comitology procedure. This means that, as is unfortunately often the case, Parliament is left out. Thank you.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Afghanistan has a difficult history behind it.
I believe that the families there are particularly close-knit and that the woman in the family plays an important role.
That is why economic development is also very important, and support for small and medium-sized enterprises in particular should be promoted especially.
And, of course, modern infrastructure is also necessary, which helps the country to develop better quite simply.

I believe that infrastructure projects in particular could help to create greater understanding among each other and, of course, through the means of information and communication technology, a different worldview could slowly begin to take hold there, while fully preserving identity.
Marine pollution only becomes a focus of interest when a spectacular incident occurs, and then there is intense discussion about the threat to our seas from this ongoing pollution.
But unfortunately, in the meantime, this often recedes into the background.
The constant and repeated violations, which contribute just as much and dramatically to the threat not only to our seas but also to our coasts, were to be taken seriously by us.
I would like to thank my colleagues, with whom we were able to discuss this, for the fact that we all consistently upheld the position that our sea must be protected.
I speak here as a citizen of a landlocked country, yet as a European, I feel a responsibility to protect our seas from ongoing pollution for cheap economic reasons.
to protect interests and to integrate the principles of the second maritime package and the third maritime package, which is urgently necessary, as also proposed by the Legal Affairs Committee.
Madam President, colleagues, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Obiol Sidjama, on his excellent report.
Worldwide, the respect for human rights is very poor in many countries.
But also here in Europe, if we think for example of Belarus.
Therefore, the European Union must significantly intensify its efforts by implementing human rights policy in all areas and setting clear standards.
In our understanding, human rights are indivisible.
This can be achieved, for example, during negotiations for a new agreement with Russia by including a binding human rights clause that influences all areas of negotiation.
Furthermore, I would like to advocate once again for the Subcommittee on Human Rights to become a main committee.
Okay. The EPP D group calls on the government and the Chinese Communist Party to conduct the upcoming human rights dialogue in a constructive manner.
This would significantly ease the relationship between the EU and China.
We have a genuine interest in improving bilateral relations.
But this dialogue must also be conducted honestly.
We will have to maintain our legitimate demands on China.
In our view, the civil rights activist should be released immediately.
Thus, talks with the Dalai Lama as the religious leader of Tibet are to be resumed.
And so the Chinese region of Tibet must be made immediately accessible to journalists and UN human rights experts.
In my opinion, the People's Republic of China has shown before the Olympic Games that it can grant more press freedom, for example, without endangering the stability of the country.
Now she should have the courage to tackle new reforms - reforms on re-education camps, the rights of the accused, the death penalty, freedom of religion, freedom of assembly.
They should really address these human rights and engage in dialogue with us.
Madam President. We welcome today's decision by the Czech Senate with great joy and extend our heartfelt congratulations.
In response, President Klaus argued, among other things, that the Lisbon Treaty was still dead because it had been rejected by the referendum in Ireland.

In doing so, he rides as a political zombie, attacking majority decisions of his own parliament and the Senate, and confirming his disgraceful and sectarian attitude in other areas of politics as well.
Fortunately, after the positive votes, he only makes a fool of himself.
We Greens are positive and constructive towards the European integration process, of course also with critical remarks where necessary.
Once again, heartfelt thanks to the Czech Senate, Parliament, and Government.

Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, last week we heard from Mr Mahmalbaf in a Committee on Foreign Affairs which, to my delight, was convened as a new committee for Members of Parliament.

an Iranian film director who told us quite clearly that there was twenty percent democracy in Iran before this election, and after this election, which he considered a coup, there is no democracy at all.
I also agree with this description. It was indeed an electoral coup, which, through massive electoral fraud, deprived the majority of the Iranian population, who had voted for change, of their right.
Mr President of the Council, I am particularly interested in one thing: there will be an inauguration for the re-elected Mr Ahmadinejad in mid-August.
What is currently being discussed in the Council and with the Member States?
Will there be an official, formal representation of the European Union and also of the member states here?
I hope there won't be any, because I think that after this coup d'Ã©tat, there should be no official representation of the European Union or even of the
Member states will be present, and I am all in favor of further dialogue, but no one from the European Union is expected to be officially represented at this inauguration.
What is your position on this?
How is that being handled at the moment? Thank you.
Mr Giegold, one minute. The crisis in Europe was not just caused by unethical behaviour in the financial markets, Mr Barroso.
There is the growing social inequality, there are the dangerous and non-solidary macroeconomic imbalances between the member countries, and there is Europe's dependence on rising resource prices.

The citizens of Europe deserve a Commission that repeatedly puts these deeper causes on the agenda, instead of taboos, instead of doing the opposite, instead of shifting the responsibility onto the member states.
We need genuine European coordination of economic and fiscal policy.
We need fiscal cooperation in Europe that puts an end to tax dumping.
Only then will it be possible to halt social division and finance the necessary ecological investments.
We need a policy that consistently promotes green technologies and lifestyles so that the EU's dependence on finite resources decreases sharply.
This is an ecological green revolution. I don't find any of this in your program, Mr. Barroso.
That is the reason why I cannot vote for you.
We need a revolution of democracy. Mr Barroso, imagine you are a great person.
If you were to stand alone in Europe, facing an election with no other candidates, how many votes do you think you would get?
What would the citizens do?
You would have listened to you today and seen that you promised everyone everything.
Hopefully, you would also get the information about what you did five years ago.
You have promised most of them a great deal.
One must compare what they have promised before, what they are promising now, and what is to be expected.
I think that is very little.
They stand for the old, failed Europe, for contributing to the financial crisis, for the Commission's failure to address climate issues, and, and, and.
I would side with the majority of European citizens because I believe they would get no more than ten or twelve or fifteen of the votes.
I would like to advocate for maintaining the new proposal, because after all, it is clear that the negotiations in Honduras have failed.
There is no joint proposal for this election.
This election is illegitimate because the current president came to power through a coup.
That is to say, I ask the plenary to give its approval to the Presidium's proposal for this change, that the elections be removed.
Democracy needs a revolution, and it's never wrong, Mr. Dartmouth colleague, to speak out for transparency, Mr. Verhofstadt.
And you, in the Swedish Presidency, could be a shining example and really tell us how it will have gone.
There is the issue of the very undignified horse-trading over top positions in the European project, and Mr Barroso could lead the way in appointing commissioners.
Germany and Austria provide a negative example, but unfortunately others do too.
Qualified people are sitting here in the hall, but they have no chance of gaining access.

Please be brave now that the Lisbon Treaty has been adopted, and be honest and say that we need much clearer decision-making structures, transparent decision-making structures for commissions and top positions.
And it should be possible to find the right people with so much expertise here in the European Parliament and not have to build them up in some federal states.
Mr President, the topic we are discussing here this evening has already been on the agenda of the European Parliament several times.
As is well known, the Commission bases the granting of the aid on the conditions set by the International Monetary Fund.
That has already been mentioned a few times.
Against this background, there have been repeated requests from the EP to the Commission.

In November 2008, the EP called on the Commission to present an analysis of the effects of the behavior of banks that had transferred their assets from the member countries that had recently joined at that time.
On April 24th of this year, the EP reiterated this demand.

Furthermore, the EP has demanded to be informed about the letters of intent concluded in detail between the Commission and the Member States receiving aid, which outline the conditions for the aid in detail.
To the best of my knowledge, these requests have not been answered to this day.
My first question, therefore, is: is it true that these requests have not yet been answered?
If that is true, then my second question is: Why have these requests not been answered so far?
My third question is then: When can we expect a response to these requests?
Ladies and gentlemen, the GUE/NGL will not be supporting this resolution.
The Stockholm Programme completely misses the mark on the real challenges of the present.
The core error is that a Europe of rights is being established, which is granted to EU citizens, but not to other people living in Europe.
The same citizens and human rights are not to be granted to them.
On the one hand, the EU wants to join the Charter of Human Rights, which we welcome, but on the other hand, migrants are sorted out according to the principle of legal or illegal.
Frontex is being massively upgraded to combat so-called illegal migration, and I tell you, this completely distorts the view of an unbiased immigration policy.
This is where Stockholm fails.
Another problem is the completely unbalanced relationship between security and freedom.
Yes, there is no freedom without security, but there is also no security without freedom. Freedom is not a bargaining chip, but a universal legal right of every human being.

Stockholm, on the other hand, symbolizes the EU's security obsession, with the creation of enormous supranational databases without adequate control mechanisms, which merge intelligence and police data across Europe.
This makes the right to informational self-determination of people, waste paper, and the vision of a transparent person a reality.
Allow me, finally, as an East German representative, to state that, twenty years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, it is unbearable for me to witness Europe increasingly becoming a fortress.
Mr. Chairman, Commissioner, you are right. The railway system is a very safe system compared to other modes of transport.

While there are many positive aspects, liberalization in the form of fragmentation of individual companies, separation of infrastructure and operations, outsourcing of maintenance work, and leasing of equipment and personnel has indeed brought about a great deal of uncertainty.
In my opinion, it must be ensured that the national safety authorities issue safety certificates and authorisations in accordance with ERA regulations, according to the Railway Agency.
Are there enough controls?
for example, it is ensured that the training of the staff, the certifications and the working conditions are properly checked.
In this context, what is the position on the introduction of a uniform Community certificate?
What about the European train driver's licence?
Efforts regarding ERTMS must be further intensified.
The recently created implementation plan you alluded to must be binding and must not be delayed due to financial or nationalistic considerations.
Efforts to introduce the technical specifications TSI must be continued and expanded.
This would be a significant advancement in the homologation of the material and would provide a higher level of safety in the maintenance of the material.
Many of the recent railway accidents and near misses are due to inadequate maintenance.
For cost reasons. For cost reasons, in particular, the intensity is neglected and the intervals of the maintenance work are extended.
What about a Europe-wide certification system for maintenance workshops?
In my opinion, everything must be done to prevent each individual Member State from reverting to their old rules and acting differently and arbitrarily once again.
Border crossings between individual member states are particularly a security risk.
How does the Commission intend to address this problem in the short term?
And in the assessment you make, I want you to take the social aspects into account. Thank you.
We need a revolution of democracy. Mr President, Commissioner, good morning in this new world of the Lisbon Treaty. This is an opportunity for you.
I have been following your reports in this house for eleven years now, previously as a journalist, and ultimately they are very similar.
Now, however, you have the opportunity to look forward.

The fact that the expertise of this House is being utilized is not entirely coincidental. Just look around the room - I see colleagues SÃ¶ndergaard and Chaci Makakis, there is Mr. Staas, there is my colleague Mr. Ehrenhauser from our list. Let us relaunch the work of the Court of Auditors.
Look at what works elsewhere, in Germany, where the economic efficiency and relevance of expenditures can be assessed, in Austria, and develop a plan.

Do you perhaps have a concept, as part of an initiative report that will be presented in Parliament, on how to significantly improve what you are doing so that you can actually fulfill your responsibilities?
We need a revolution of democracy.
I remember very well that the debates we hear today had already begun in this House ten years ago.
I would strongly urge you, Commissioner, to really take to heart what comes from Arlem Desir, but also from the Greens and some left-wing Members of Parliament.

Don't you see that with the approach the European Union has taken to the negotiations, we cannot act as an honest broker to rectify the imbalance? I think that, in conjunction with what we are currently experiencing in Copenhagen in these hours and days, we actually need a new approach.
In many ways, the developing countries are no longer developing countries in what they are doing today.
Emerging countries, developed countries, and very self-assured.
If Europe fails to manage to make a fresh start with fair conditions, then we will end up where we do not want to be, namely with protectionism and the year 1833 also in Europe.
Mr President, I would just like to use the blue card to correct something.
Support in Austria is not only granted to one person.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a microfinance instrument for the unemployed, those at risk of unemployment, and above all for people who have no access to normal credit markets, is a good intention and is supported in principle by our group.
However, what the Commission and the Council have achieved so far in this process in terms of performance is simply insufficient, partly incorrect, and cannot be supported by our group.
The first point of criticism is the issue of financial resources.
What is on the table in terms of financial resources is not financial resources for a program to combat unemployment; it cannot be described as a microfinance program, at most it is nano-finance.
Secondly, we are fundamentally opposed to such sleight of hand, which has no effect, comes at the expense of other programs, and thus evaporates without end.
Third, it is also the view that the sustainability and success of such a program must include organic mentoring and coaching.
Many new start-ups, especially in the microfinance sector, fail, so the programme must also ensure this is addressed.
Fourthly, it must be ensured that social security benefits in the Member States are not withdrawn for the use of this programme, otherwise it will be ineffective.
This means that unemployment cannot be combated sustainably.
We will reject it in this form.
Mr. President, today, after eight years, we basically all know that the previous military-focused Afghanistan strategy has failed.
The imbalance between military operations on the one hand and insufficient resources for civilian purposes effectively prevents an improvement in the living conditions in Afghanistan.
That is why our most important message as the GUE NGL is that a radical change of strategy is needed.
We need a radical change of strategy away from the military and above all towards the people.
This means that forty percent of Afghans are unemployed. More than half of them live in extreme poverty, without access to healthcare or adequate education.
The social question must be brought to the forefront, and that is what we expect from the Council, the Commission, and all those involved.
This naturally includes strengthening responsible government action, strengthening agriculture, and integrating former Taliban fighters.
But I tell you quite honestly: anyone who only goes half way down this path and reverts to military adventures is squandering every opportunity.
