It is a truly important moment that we are commemorating the Holocaust of Roma and Sinti for the first time in the European Parliament today.
Let me begin with the farewell letter that a fourteen-year-old boy wrote to Robert Reinhardt in 1943 before his deportation from a German children's home to Auschwitz.
He wrote I have found my parents again.
We are on the transport to the concentration camp.
I have mentally prepared myself to the point where I can endure death.
I would like to thank you once again for everything you have done for me.
Greetings to all, see you in heaven.
Yours, Robert.

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy did not return, like five hundred other Roma and Sinti. Although Roma and Sinti were among the first victims of industrial-scale mass killings, along with Jews, today, sixty-six years later, the full truth about this remains unspoken.
And the complicity of mainstream society is often covered up.
We need the whole truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust of Roma and Sinti must be recognized and punished as a crime against humanity so that this history does not repeat itself.
We must fight against the prejudices against these people with passion.
We must put a stop to racist abuse and acts of violence, such as those that took place in Hungary the year before last, and we must do so with civil courage.
Freedom, equality, and solidarity are not privileges for a select few, but the rights of all, because human and citizens' rights are indivisible.
Dear ladies and gentlemen, colleagues. In my view, the issue now is to truly utilize the possibilities of the law.
We have doubts as to whether these opportunities are really being fully exploited institutionally.
We see flaws in the process. To this day, we, as a parliament, have not received the list of candidates in advance, only the final result.
It would be simple for you to send us the current ones for the executive directors.

We have clearly seen the lack of gender equality in the appointment of positions, and we have doubts, due to certain incidents in the process, that the member states are truly appointing these institutions in the European interest.
This and the other points in our letter justify asking a fundamental question.
But beyond that, it is of course about the suitability of the individual persons, and each person must be assessed individually and according to their competencies.
There, we see two major problems.

During the hearings, we witnessed one of the candidates denying that it is a European institution, instead referring to it as a network of supervisory authorities, and even when asked, he was unwilling to correct this statement.
When asked whether they are prepared to make all lobby contacts with the financial industry transparent, we did not receive any clear statements.
We have sent a letter to all three candidates, and for us, the outcome of the vote depends on whether we receive clear and comprehensive responses to it.
Mr President, we, as the Social Democratic Group, wish to table the same motion.
However, I would like to recommend to my colleague Mauro and the distinguished House that we phrase it a bit more precisely.
We are dealing with a truly enormous influx.

And Italy, like every other country in the Mediterranean region, is certainly overwhelmed by the current problem and unable to solve it on its own. And Italy will certainly not be the only country confronted with the massive influx of refugees.
We can assume that Malta, Greece and Spain will also be confronted with the problem in the foreseeable future.

Therefore, we would like to request that we formulate the title of the debate very precisely, namely a statement by the Commission on immediate measures by the European Union to support Italy and other EU countries affected by the influx of refugees.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I expressly welcome the outcome of the conciliation procedure.

The implementation of the regulation will ensure that, in the field of bus and coach transport, firstly, a high level of protection comparable to that of other modes of transport is achieved for all passengers, including those with reduced mobility.

Firstly, it achieves high levels of safety for people, secondly, it ensures a high general level of consumer protection, and thirdly, it takes into account the special circumstances of a transport sector that is predominantly characterized by small and medium-sized enterprises.

This means that the extreme demands, which would have made bus transport almost completely impossible due to excessive requirements, are off the table, as are demands where the majority of the member states would have fallen completely outside the scope of the regulation.
Bus transport services that benefit citizens in general must also offer a high quality of service to disabled people and those with reduced mobility.
They should have a right to help in the interests of social integration, and this help should be free of charge.
Madam President, I would like to congratulate everyone, especially my colleague Mr Kancian, for his efforts in the difficult and lengthy process of drafting a compromise on this challenging issue.
There were successes that have already been mentioned, but there were also disappointments, such as the scope and other peculiarities that have already been described.
With this compromise for bus transport, we have covered passenger rights for all modes of transport.
The next necessary step is to create a common, coherent and efficient framework programme for all passenger rights.
Fair and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the EU's credibility among European citizens.
In order to be credible, it is therefore essential to respect the coherence of rights for the different modes of transport.
It is inevitable that fundamentally different criteria apply to the rights of airplane passengers than, for example, to train passengers.

That is why it is particularly important, when drafting a framework programme, not to think in terms of the lowest and weakest standards, but rather to keep ambitious goals in mind for the benefit of the citizens.

Madam President, Mr President, dear colleagues. We are in the midst of a major economic crisis, we have been talking about it for months, and that is all true, but we usually just discuss it in headlines and then carry on making decisions as if nothing had happened.
I believe it's because we don't behave concretely or honestly enough in Parliament either, but it's just this headline-grabbing politics that's going on.
What is actually being done to promote growth and stability?
Do we ourselves contribute to managing finances more orderly and wisely?
Do we really critically examine whether we are making the right expenditures, or does each of us not have a new idea every day about where more money can be spent?

If we do not have the strength to concentrate the financial resources on future projects, that is, to engage in debate and decision-making, then it is pointless to talk about innovation and research without providing the necessary funds.
That is relatively dishonest.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, we must also pursue a policy that stimulates the economy and doesn't spend all day thinking about how we can disrupt industry or the economy.
We cheerfully continue to make decisions, constantly demanding new decisions today as well, which disrupt the economy in its development.
Does anyone really believe that the issue of binding energy efficiency targets - just to mention one example - contributes to driving the economy forward?
Do you really believe that we have stimulated the economy with our decisions, which we have often made in connection with energy?
Or have you been causing a disturbance?
I would like us to talk about this a bit more honestly and then make a few fewer decisions, but perhaps make the decisions that really move things forward.
It is more strenuous, more laborious, and will also mean conflict, but that is the essence of democracy.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the demand for a financial transaction tax is not new. Opponents of globalization have been calling for such a tax for several years now.
But even five years ago, hardly anyone would have believed that it could be implemented in the foreseeable future.
But this week it is on the agenda in the European Parliament, along with a CO2 tax and Euro Bonds, and I think that's a good thing.
I can only welcome and support the financial instruments that Anni Podimata proposes in her report, and I think we will vote in favor of them accordingly.
They are urgently needed instruments.
So far, the consolidation of public finances has focused solely on cutting spending.
The reduction in public spending primarily affects workers, pensioners, and the poor, i.e., those who rely on the welfare state.
The revenue side of the public sector has so far been completely overlooked.
It is the second adjustment that can be made to consolidate public finances.
Above all, however, the revenue side also allows for the main contributors to the public debt crisis to be adequately involved in the reduction of public debt.
To consolidate public finances, an increase in tax revenues is simply indispensable.

In fact, the high level of public debt is primarily a result of the nationalization of private debt, namely the assumption of debts by private banks and the financing of the consequences of the financial crisis by the public sector.
The states are therefore by no means solely responsible for the debt crisis.
It is therefore not only logical, but also politically necessary, to ask the financial sector to contribute.
With the financial transaction tax, this sector would finally be held accountable as the main cause of public debt and would contribute to the reduction of this debt.
This is an important political signal sent out by this report, if it is adopted as it was presented.
But we also consider Euro Bonds to be a sensible and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to reducing debt than all sanctions or more or less well-intentioned advice.

The complaints of some surplus countries that their interest burdens would increase through Eurobonds are not acceptable, because at the same time these surplus countries also earn money through their exports to the deficit countries.
This can then be criticized as a transfer union.
But anyone who wants a social Europe, who wants the EU to remain united in the future, must at least agree in principle to a transfer union.
Finally, I would like to say to the Commission that I hope it will finally present the proposals for a financial transaction tax that have been demanded for over a year now.
Mr President, the rescue umbrellas are meant to protect EU member states from insolvency.
However, they burden people with brutal austerity programs and let the perpetrators off scot-free. Moreover, the Commission is now also interfering in national wage policies.
Dear Hahn, it is absurd and it brings tears to one's eyes to hear this formal argumentation here, that none of this was meant to be socio-political.
This position is completely unacceptable. Wage policy is not the EU's responsibility, and this policy of the Commission is in blatant contradiction to the idea of this European Union.
The European Union was never a project for downward wage competition and social dumping.
It can be read there about wage rigidity, which is supposed to be reduced.
This means that wages should reflect market conditions.
Ladies and gentlemen, here blind people are talking about the color of humanity; those who formulate something like this have no idea about collective bargaining systems.
They interfere with collective bargaining autonomy and reduce the much-vaunted autonomy of the social partners and social dialogue to absurdity.
I want to make it clear: This Parliament is called upon to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining, protect social dialogue, and prevent further erosion of social security.
We need measures against a counterproductive austerity policy and punitive actions. Thank you.
Mr Barroso, you are a clever man, but you have not answered my question.

That is why I am asking again: When Mr. Oettinger says that we currently suspect that certain plants that are still in operation will not survive our stress tests, I interpret this to mean that you are aware that these plants are so poorly secured that they will not meet the criteria.
Why don't you take action today?
In my opinion, this is a real danger.

Mrs. Gabriele Zimmer now has the floor. I would actually like to ask the two representatives from the Council and the Commission why they believe they need to present their arguments on this topic using speech bubbles.
I believe it helps no one if it is not explicitly stated that, in preparation for the Istanbul Conference, the Member States of the European Union and the European Union itself
it must finally fully meet its commitments to development aid and that it is in no way acceptable for Member States to increasingly shirk this responsibility.
It is unacceptable that one billion people still go hungry every day, and that most of them live in LDCs, the poorest countries in the world.

It is unacceptable that a large portion of our development aid is not going towards the promotion and development of agricultural structures, but that this proportion has rapidly decreased in recent years, with one billion people suffering from hunger.
And then to talk about it: We hope that the LDCs become more shock-resistant, I think that's getting to be cynical.
I urge you to address the problems in a concrete and clear manner and to assume concrete obligations in order to actually help the LDCs.
In the context of the internal market, public procurement law and the awarding of public contracts are essential components.

Mr. Barnier, when you say that you also want to promote social integration in this context, I have to ask: I have heard very little about the protection of social rights, and I have heard very little about the protection of collective bargaining agreements.
That is one of the basic rules that you, as you say, do not want to question yourself.

If one wants to protect basic rules, one must ensure in the future that elementary social standards are protected when awarding public contracts, that collective agreements are not undermined, and that wage dumping is prevented.
This is part of a modernized public procurement law.
I expressly state that fundamental social rights must no longer be subordinated to economic freedoms and free competition.
Either we want a social Europe or we want a lasting conflict with the people who are turning away from this Europe, in which they do not see their interests safeguarded.
Dear Madam President, Dear Commissioner Kruse, Radio frequencies are a precious and limited resource that must be managed with care, foresight, and from a societal perspective.
That is why the Radio Spectrum Policy Programme is of particular importance.
Radio frequencies must be used efficiently, taking into account economic, social and cultural aspects.
To achieve this, the technical capabilities must be fully utilized in all band areas to generate the highest possible efficiency.

The basis of radio frequency policy must be the telecommunications package adopted last year, as it also stipulates that the radio frequency management of the EU and its member states must equally meet cultural, social, and economic interests.
This must be taken into account, especially when harmonizing the use of frequencies in the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the digital dividend I is being carried out at very different speeds in the Member States.
Further opening of the UAF band, especially below eight hundred megahertz, should therefore only be considered after taking into account the experiences with the clearing of this band.
Many technical and financial issues have not yet been conclusively resolved.

The issue of interference and the question of cost compensation for cultural institutions and local authorities in the technical conversion, for example in the field of wireless microphones, has not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
When distributing frequency bands, the various interests must be weighed against each other responsibly.

On the one hand, the widespread provision of mobile broadband networks is a fundamental requirement in the interests of European citizens. At the same time, however, the development of public and private broadcasting must continue to be taken into account as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity.
We must set the course for the technical development of Europe's positioning in the field of digital information technology and cultural diversity.
Mr President, dear Mr Rehn, I would like to say first of all that you have described it, the situation has worsened.
The Eurozone is experiencing a widening gap between countries that are recovering and those that are weaker.
and the costs of supporting the weaker countries are continuing to rise.

In this situation, I have a few questions for you. As Commissioner for Monetary Affairs, I ask you: On the two accounts of the ECB system, liabilities and claims between the central banks have accumulated to over four hundred billion euros.
This is because the banks are still not adequately financed by the capital market.
How do you assess these liabilities that are not provided for in the Eurosystem?
Then the big problem, why we are not making progress with the restructuring of the debt, is that the banking system, as Mrs. Ford also said, is not set up correctly.
The proposal for a European restructuring system has been delayed.
When will the Commission present this?
And as Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Affairs, how do you assess this delay?
What do you do to make it go faster?
Then we saw, as we Greens had predicted for some time, that the measures taken against Greece and Portugal would not work as long as the macroeconomic conditions in the Eurozone were not improved.
We still have absolutely rising interest burdens from a macroeconomic perspective for these countries.
amid increasing capital exports and capital flight in some of these countries
And we still have a lack of demand from several European partner countries, especially from the strong Euro countries.
And we have rising resource and food prices, at least if you take out the recent ups and downs.

Besides the bailouts for these countries and the financial aid, I wonder what measures are being taken to ensure that the weaker countries receive macroeconomic relief in areas such as taxes, external demand, and interest rates?
And you?
I would therefore encourage you to propose a strong package that improves the macroeconomic conditions of these countries in the Eurozone.

And finally, in my view, the measures have hit the weakest in Greece, Portugal, and Spain against the spirit of the EU treaty, while the stronger, the wealthy, have so far not been called upon to bear any of the burden.
What measures are you taking to ensure that even the wealthy are called upon to contribute to the costs of this crisis?
Mr President, Mrs Kinga GÃ¶nz is a Member of my group.
One can be against Ferenc Joachani, one can be for Ferenc Joachani.
One can reject Kinga GÃ¶ncz as a politician or be in favor of her.
This can certainly be determined freely and independently by anyone, whether they are in favor of or against a person's political beliefs.
The debate we are having here is about the last dictatorship in Europe.
And we are leading them through one of the most brutal and bloody dictators on the European continent.
I find it absolutely unacceptable that an elected democratic member of my group is compared to a bloodthirsty dictator.

I believe that Parliament must also reject this, especially from the representative of a party that is known for its hatred and persecution of the Roma minority in Hungary, which is unparalleled in Europe.
If any person here does not have the right to criticize Mrs. Kinga GÃ¶nz, it is Mrs. Mauer.
Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, dear visitors, Europe's cultural diversity is a valuable asset that must be preserved and further developed in the future.
In order for this to be possible, we must address the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the cultural and creative sector.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value, but it also represents a significant economic factor.
In the EU, approximately five million people are employed in the cultural sector.
This corresponds to approximately two and a half times total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector that is developing faster than many other areas of the economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven by the content offered by the cultural sector, just as the nature and quality of content has changed and evolved through technology.
We therefore need to create framework conditions for the cultural and creative industries in which they can develop sustainably in the face of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible and legally secure system in which everyone can develop equally.
Culture and the creative industry are a driving force for Europe.
That is why we must also focus on this area in the field of school and vocational education.
We must impart cultural and creative competencies to young people and also in the offerings of lifelong learning.
However, we must also better strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural workers, not just their business competencies, but also their media literacy in the field of new technologies.
We need framework conditions in which cultural workers can secure their livelihood.
Therefore, we will have to intensively address the issues of copyright, social security, and intellectual property, as well as open access to information and content, in order to further develop the

to ensure the creative and cultural industries in a digital environment in the future and to preserve Europe's cultural diversity and cultural heritage as an essential characteristic of the European Union.

Mr President, dear colleague Kellam, dear colleagues from the Baltic countries, dear colleagues. Today we are commemorating in a special way the expulsions and mass deportations from the Baltic countries.
These expulsions are among the darkest events in European history.
Indeed, the last century was also and not without reason called the century of expulsions.
And today we all bow our heads in respect for the victims of these inhumane acts.
In this context, we demand a comprehensive investigation of Soviet history and, in particular, the atrocities of Stalinism.

And modern Russia should not understand this as a political attack, but as support for the re-evaluation of its own history, which, like the history of other European countries, is marked by times of sunshine and shadow.
But just as we think of the victims from the Baltic countries, we think of the Armenians who were expelled from Turkey at the beginning of the last century.
We commemorate the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
Deporatations in Europe reached a particular peak in the middle of the century under the Nazi regime and the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
The expulsions after World War II also left deep wounds, as did the expulsions during the Yugoslav War.
We must also not forget, however, that many colonial powers were characterized by expulsions.
We must demand a serious examination of the various forms of displacement and the specious justifications for them.
And this also includes clarifying guilt and punishing the guilty, insofar as this is still possible, as is currently the case with Mladic.

But the crucial answer is European unity, especially through and with the independent Baltic countries, and a clear commitment to continuing the European unification process that has not yet been completed.
This historical task is what we owe not only to ourselves, but especially to the victims of the many expulsions in Europe.
Many female politicians from all countries in Europe, from East and West, have worked on it.
For example, consider the Danzig declaration signed by Polish President Wojciechowski and German Federal President Rau.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must be vigilant, even towards the first signs of displacement, as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all statements, such as the one that Arab immigrants should be sent back across the Mediterranean in boats, and we must resist when some want to abolish Europe's borderless achievements and bring back a new narrow-minded nationalism.

Let us bow our heads in reverence for all the victims of expulsion and deportation, but let us unanimously commit ourselves to the continuation of European unity as the only real guarantee against such a future.
The politics that brought so much misfortune to people in Europe and beyond in the last century. Never forget, never again were demands that arose immediately after the Second World War.
They have lost none of their validity; they are best preserved in a united Europe.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues. I had the opportunity to experience the referendum on the independence of South Sudan as a parliamentary election observer, and I was impressed by the overwhelming support of the South Sudanese people for determining the future of their country themselves.
I also saw the great expectations among the people, who saw their country's independence as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands of so-called internally displaced persons, who were driven by the decades-long fighting in the south to the refugee camps in the north, set out on their way to their former South Sudanese homeland.

And of course, in addition to the independence of the country, the people of South Sudan want above all to live in peace and pursue a path towards a happier future after all those decades of conflict, during which millions of South Sudanese had to lose their lives.
On July 9th, the new state of South Sudan is set to officially become independent and expand the family of nations in our world.
The starting conditions are as bad as they can be, and a lot has already been said about that here.
Seventy of the people live as normalized cattle breeders, eighty are illiterate. The conflict over Abyei is escalating into a military conflict.
There were already dead and wounded there.

As if that were not enough, rivalries between tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also increasing, and according to estimates by observers, more than 1,000 people have already lost their lives since January.
The wounded and mutilated are barely counted.
Sudan was already among the failed states.
There is a danger that the state of South Sudan is already beginning as a failed state.
I am firmly convinced that Europe has a great responsibility towards this region.
given the colonial past of the countries there. Together with the UN and the African Union, this is where a common European foreign policy is needed, and it can prove itself here as well.
This is not just about money, but also about supporting the fragile, emerging civil society.

And we must negotiate hard with those who hold the fate of the country in their hands, namely the tribal leaders, who lead the military groups, so that they do not disappoint the hopes of their people in the country. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. I am very grateful to my colleague Mr Bartolozzi for having made Mongolia the subject of a debate in the European Parliament with his initiative to submit this question.
While the former Soviet states of Central Asia are now discussed in Parliament from various perspectives, Mongolia and its situation have only received very limited attention here.
It was Mongolia, quite wrongly, that as a state of the former communist bloc, was relatively quick to take advantage of its independence and embarked on a path towards democratising its society.

As early as 1992, the Mongolians adopted a democratic constitution, and since then, several elections have taken place, which, according to observers, have generally had a democratic and correct course, which is far from being a matter of course for the states in this region.

The Mongolian government has been trying for several years to combat corruption by law and in 2010 imposed a moratorium on the death penalty, something that even some major democratic countries have not yet managed to achieve.
Nevertheless, the three million inhabitants of this large country, dominated by extreme climatic conditions, are suffering from the consequences of an ongoing transformation process.
And so, a rural population that still lives predominantly in a nomadic fashion is crowding into the few cities that are not prepared for this in terms of infrastructure.
The country's mineral resources are not extracted in an environmentally friendly manner.
Energy problems complicate civil and economic life.
Sandwiched between its large neighbors Russia and China, Mongolia is at risk of becoming even more dependent on these countries than it already is.

Mongolia's efforts and successes in democratizing its societyâand here I see the glass as half full rather than half emptyâshould be recognized, as they are exemplary for the region and demonstrate what is possible despite a difficult past.
Mongolia should continue to receive our support, not only through aid programs, but also by the European Union having a direct presence in the Mongolian capital with its own
Representation as a sign that the fate of Mongolia is not indifferent to us Europeans and that European interests will no longer be represented from the embassy in Beijing. One more sentence, please.
I am very disappointed that the Conference of Presidents was not prepared to lend additional emphasis to this concern by approving a resolution of the Parliament.
But, dear colleague, of course I recognize this right.
I can only assume and hope that you also recognize the right that the position of the Dutch government is not declared ex cathedra, but is open to discussion in a multinational democracy.
I have absolute respect for Mr. RÃ¼the, who is in favor of a two-fold increase in the EU budget.
I have taken note of that, and I am pleased that you have listened to me attentively, because in this Parliament, the positions of all governments are openly discussed.
I didn't quite understand the meaning of your question, but what I think I hear is that you also identify with democracy.
That is, after all, progress.
First, I reacted so excitedly because I am still upset that we were unable to get a joint resolution on security in place here, because the absolutization of a position was more important than unity.

Secondly, I explained at the time in the debate, and I will reiterate it now, that I have also learned and now see that we need to do more in the area of increased safety regulations for European nuclear power plants, exert more pressure, and show more initiative.
That is precisely why I was in favor of the joint resolution, and that is why I believe we should support the Commissioner and not constantly attack him.

Madam President, regarding the intermediate category. I would have certainly been able to imagine other solutions at the beginning, Mr. Pieper, especially since the regions that currently have the highest debt and will no longer have it after 2013 will receive a transitional arrangement.
However, the discussion revealed that we need to take into account other regions that have been particularly affected by the crisis.
We are talking about one and fifty regions at present.
Given the large number of affected regions, it would be negligent not to establish an intermediate category.
Only in this way can a reliable framework be established for the responsible promotion of these regions, which must overcome development deficits through their own efforts.
Otherwise, there is much light and much shadow to be found in the Pieper report.

We criticise, among other things, the lack of a clear commitment to much more decisive poverty reduction and consider the formulations contained herein for linking cohesion policy with conditionalities that force member states to implement reforms to be unclear and highly open to interpretation.
Point by point, cohesion policy must remain an instrument of social balance and solidarity, in all regions.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues. Interregional cooperation is becoming increasingly important in the future.
Cross-border cooperation and macro-regional collaboration are extremely important in an increasingly interconnected Europe for achieving the goals of the year 2020.
Border regions still face special challenges today.

Cross-border concepts and projects in areas such as infrastructure, business cooperation, research collaboration, labor market development, and further education are the driving force behind large parts of the European Union.
We need clear and simplified structures for the management of interregional projects.
Different national requirements among project partners often make cooperation and the realization of concrete, sustainable projects more difficult.
It is an important step that the Pieper report includes the demand to increase the proportion for interregional cooperation in Objective Three to seven, and I would like to strongly support this.
Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues. After almost three years of intensive work, after far more than three amendments, after countless conversations, discussions,

Debates. After the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogues, the political package, the major compromise between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers on the future labeling of food products, is now up for a vote.
This regulation aims to provide consumers with more and better information about food products, enabling them to make informed purchasing decisions.
But that's not all; the European food industry is also expected to benefit.
The goal is legal certainty, deregulation, and better legislation.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises, and it is important to know that the food sector in the European Union consists of over eighty percent of SMEs.
At the same time, this labeling must be suitable for every food and every non-alcoholic beverage, from basic foodstuffs to highly processed ready-made meals.
That is why mandatory labeling in traffic light colors is not possible, because this labeling is not suitable for staple foods.

Despite all the difficulties, despite all the political and ideological differences in Parliament, despite all the national egoisms of the member states, the compromise that has now been reached is still impressive.
Allergens will be recognizable at first glance.
The plant origin of vegetable oils is indicated.
There is origin labeling for pork, poultry, lamb, and goat meat.

For other products, a follow-up assessment will determine whether and how the origin can be indicated, for example for milk and dairy products, i.e., products that consist of a main ingredient, meat in processed form.
Imitation products, etc., must be clearly marked on the front, and the same applies to molded meat and molded fish, which are composed of and glued together from small pieces.
Nor may packaging create the impression that something is inside that is not actually there.
If a picture of fruit is on a yogurt, there must also be fruit in it, not just coloring and flavorings.
In addition, the mandatory declaration of the most important nutrients is always given per 100 grams or 100 milliliters for reasons of comparability.
Added water in meat must be labeled, the date of the first freezing in meat and fish, and many other details.
But most importantly, all information must be legible.

We have defined readability, we have established a minimum font size, and we have instructed the Commission to establish binding rules for additional factors, such as the contrast between the font and the background.
At the same time, we protect the craft industry from excessive costs and bureaucracy.
Fresh products that are not fully packaged must provide allergen information, but not the full nutritional information that can only be determined through expensive analyses.

The Commission originally wanted this, but it would have destroyed our national and regional characteristics and specialties, it would have led to a European uniformity, and that's why we prevented it.
But now we have all reached an agreement, and the reputable consumer protectionists are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

I would therefore like to thank all those involved, the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission, and in particular Commissioner Dalli, for his statements, which he will hopefully make shortly and which will cut through the Gordian knot that has formed in our political discourse.

And I am particularly grateful to the Hungarian Presidency of the Council, which has achieved something that was almost no longer to be expected - almost the squaring of the circle - the agreement on this regulation. Thank you very much.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of the Polish Presidency, allow me to join in your thanks to the rapporteur, Mrs Ayala Sender.
As mentioned earlier, the Council blocked progress on this issue from 2008 until a compromise was finally reached under the Belgian presidency.
As mentioned, improved data exchange between member states will enable cross-border prosecution of various traffic offenses throughout Europe in the future.
The goal must be to increase road safety and reduce the number of traffic fatalities and injuries.

Together with Dieter Koch's own-initiative report on road safety, which makes a number of very specific proposals, this directive, with its repressive nature, can also contribute to better compliance with these rules.
I no longer need to go into the rules, as they have already been presented positively here.
The change in the legal basis from European transport policy to police cooperation has finally allowed the Council to draft a common position.
However, this means that some countries, such as Great Britain, Ireland, and Denmark, are excluded.
As a result, once again, not all European citizens are treated equally.
Citizens must be aware of the data protection rights they have.
We have tried to strengthen this aspect so that access to the collected data, its transmission and its storage are regulated as strictly as possible.
We also placed great importance on the information.
Although the sedentary text does not fully meet the expectations of the Parliament, I am still optimistic that this is a first step in the right direction.
I hope that in the coming years we can build on this foundation to take a step towards greater harmonization of European traffic regulations.
The revision clause introduced by Parliament would definitely allow such a procedure.
I deeply regret that this text has now become embroiled in the institutional conflict between the Council and Parliament over the correlation tables.
During the trilogue, we agreed to find an overall compromise on this issue with the joint declaration.
I would just like to remind you that the European Road Federation will be meeting tomorrow.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear female colleagues, dear male colleagues. First of all, my heartfelt thanks to Mrs. Matthias for this report.

I would also like to express my heartfelt thanks to the colleagues who prepared the reports before me, Mrs. Merki and Mrs. Carvalho. This is a follow-up, and the day is approaching when we will not only be making political decisions,
but also have to prove that we are serious about research and innovation, which is the crucial question for the future viability of the European Union.
That is why I am very grateful that the representative of the Committee on Budgets also pointed out that adequate and good financial resources in this area are an important issue.

We will soon have to settle the dispute as to whether we have the strength to provide the necessary financial resources to ensure that this area of research and innovation truly becomes a central priority.
It is of central importance for the question of whether and how Europe will develop in the future.
By then, it will no longer be enough to deliver grand and small Sunday speeches; instead, facts will have to be presented.
Second point: We ourselves cannot avoid looking at whether we can use our resources more effectively, and this is very well highlighted in the report.
How do we achieve a simplification in the procedure?
How do we achieve speed?
How can we make research funding more effective?
How can we create a stronger structure and greater simplification in the sometimes still complex maze of different research funding?
Sometimes less is more. Few projects, but a lot of money invested, ultimately have a higher impact.
That is why I am grateful that we have once again taken a step forward in this report.

Of course, the European Research Council and the European Institute of Innovation and Technology will play a special role, and of course, the area of small and medium-sized enterprises is an important area.

And last but not least, we must also have a solution for the states that are not yet as advanced, while maintaining excellence as the only principle that must remain imperative in the future. We also need an answer for the states that are not yet as far along.
And in this report, the idea of a possible competition also emerges, which could perhaps be used to promote new top research centers in disadvantaged regions.
And that is an important task that still needs to be solved.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, in view of the current extraordinary situation resulting from the financial, economic, and budgetary crisis, decisions at the European level should focus on urgent and essential issues.
This is the only way to restore the trust of our citizens in the seriousness of our actions.
My report is about the strategy to prevent endless human suffering, resulting in approximately five to thirty deaths annually.
five million often severe injuries resulting from road traffic accidents, as well as the prevention of associated economic damage of 130 billion euros annually.
The number of deaths alone is equivalent to what would be expected in the crash of two hundred and fifty medium-sized commercial airliners, fully occupied.
What wouldn't we do to prevent that?
The costs of accident consequences significantly exceed the annual total budget of the European Union.
That is why I am sure that it is appropriate for us to take sustainable action in this area.

Thanks to the constructive cooperation of all shadow rapporteurs and many of my fellow Members, we have succeeded for the first time in this report to develop a unified, holistic, coherent approach to improving road safety.
It takes into account the contents of the UN Road Safety Charter 2010-2020 as well as the contents and objectives of the road safety work of the EU member states and broader circles of civil society.
Firstly, it includes ambitious, yet realistic goals for the period up to the year 2020, and the Vision Zero for the period beyond that.
By the year 2020, the number of accident fatalities must be reduced by fifty, the number of children killed by sixty, and the number of seriously injured by forty.
This is in the best interest of each and every one of our people, as well as our economy.
We recommend that the Member States break down the objectives and methods into their own territory and expect them to develop their own road safety action programmes.
Secondly, it specifies who is responsible for each activity and measure.
This is by no means just the European Union.

In the context of subsidiarity, the holistic approach means that Member States, regional or local authorities, and even individual road users must take responsibility in line with their duty to cooperate.
And thirdly, it includes how, with which instruments, activities, and measures the goals are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at the European level are just one strategy.
We cannot and do not want to do without guidelines, recommendations, and assignments.
Particular attention has been paid to subsidiarity, which means that responsibilities and areas of competence have been clearly defined, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the Commission's diverse activities.

However, since they come from a wide variety of directorates-general, such as transport, economy, consumer protection, environment, communication, research and development, internal market, and others, they are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and sometimes even contradict each other.
This is why we propose the appointment of a road safety coordinator within the European Commission.
This sustainably avoids the establishment of a road safety agency, but greatly increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
Both the selection of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically grounded approach based on comparable, high-quality data, definitions, and statistics.
We therefore call for, among other things, a harmonised analysis of injury and accident causes, as well as EU-wide data exchange while maintaining a high level of personal data protection.
Six main fields of action were identified.
They concern humans as road users, traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructure, their intelligent networking, and the special consideration of vulnerable road users.
I request approval for tomorrow.
Madam Chairperson, esteemed colleagues. Yes, we should focus on urgent and essential issues in traffic safety.
I am very convinced of this, and in my view, this primarily concerns the two biggest attention-distractors in traffic: alcohol and excessive speed.
The European Union also needs to have something to say about this and not just propose technical measures, which in my opinion are good but far from sufficient.
The lack of attention is a particularly dramatic problem for inattentive drivers, especially in cities.
That's why the speed has to be reduced here.
I was very pleasantly surprised that there was a broad majority in favor of Tempo 30 as a recommendation.

must be given special consideration, and that is included, and I think it is important and good that weak road users are finally being brought to the forefront, and I hope that these measures will finally be implemented.
That seems pointless to me, but I would like to extend an invitation to him.
I have never seen him in the discussions about Rio or about other major global conferences, but I have always heard him speaking here in the plenary.
I would really like to ask you, Mr. Colleague, to come to the committee once.
Engage with us, submit your proposals, and then we will continue to discuss the statement with you.
And the contribution to the discussion you just made, we can't really do anything with that.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your introductory remarks.
However, these general statements are not an answer to the questions that were asked.
Because the questions are aimed at determining: Is it certain that we will also reach results quickly?
The industries that we want to exempt from these additional burdens or where we want to establish fair conditions need planning security.
We therefore need decisions soon.
We need swift decisions, reliable decisions and also clear statements from the Commission.
This process has been going on for a very, very long time.

We all knew that this was a very complicated procedure that we were embarking on, but back then, in the compromise on the Emissions Trading Directive, we also said, "We're doing this with the Emissions Trading Directive."
on the condition that the industries in Europe, which are thereby excessively burdened, can experience relief, because otherwise they cannot compete with other areas of the world.
I expect that what was the basis for the deal back then will become a resolution in Parliament, with the Council, with the Commission, and that it will be implemented as such.

I'm a bit concerned that along the way, the circle of those affected is getting smaller, that one, if I may put it this way, is becoming increasingly narrow-minded in their perspective, that more and more areas are being excluded.

It's not just about steel, it's about aluminum. You know that it's about many other areas, chemistry, etc., that you simply don't implement in reality what was the political basis for the decision at the time.
Commissioner, you rightly pointed out that the situation for industry in Europe has not become easier since this decision, but rather it has become much more difficult.
We have a completely new situation, we have a much more competitive environment.
We are all fighting for this and are saying in Sunday sermons that industry is a very important area for the future development of Europe.
Yesterday, we heard some wise speeches here again.

I expect the Parliament - I believe that what was agreed upon back then will also be implemented now, not for the benefit of the industries, but for the people who work in these companies, for the jobs and thus also for Europe's future opportunities.
Commissioner, do you know of any example that would actually justify the effort and the many millions, indeed billions, spent on developing these body scanners?
Are there examples that prove that this has increased safety?
Mr President, I would like to start by thanking the Council representative for the very clear description of the current situation.
We have constantly heard in this debate that it is about improving the situation for working women who have to decide for a child.
In my opinion, the directive focuses too much on increasing maternity protection to twenty weeks.
But do we really believe that the decision to have a child can be reduced to twenty weeks of maternity leave?

As a mother of three children, I am well aware that comprehensive concepts for family-friendly services and good offers for families are necessary to positively influence the decision to have a child and to establish equal opportunities for women.
The present draft of the guidelines does not do justice to the diverse, and in some cases very good, proposal and overall concepts in some Member States.
We need flexible solutions that are tailored to the situation in the member states and societies and the resulting needs of families.
Maximum demands and wishful concerts do not lead to a solution here.
That is why we must first develop a solid and realistic basis for negotiations here in Parliament.
The comprehensive protection of mothers and the well-being of children have the highest priority here.
This can be ensured in different ways with different models.
Those who want to get somewhere by charging headfirst into a wall won't necessarily reach their destination faster.
A lack of willingness to compromise does not open doors or build bridges.
A moderate proposal would be a better solution for more maternity protection in order to move forward here.

I believe that we really need to look for a new approach based on the Commission's draft directive, with more flexibility for different concepts in individual Member States, in order to significantly improve maternity protection for women and also protection for children in their first months of life.
This will not work with the draft that is before us today, which certainly did not have the broad majority support, as some colleagues have tried to make clear today.
I would like to see a bit more flexibility here, a bit more realism, and a better look at what the member states have already achieved today, without questioning our fundamental demands for that.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to make a few comments on the tax agreement between Germany and Switzerland, as others have already done.
Instead of putting a stop to tax evasion, which would be sensible, and instead of closing loopholes for tax evaders, they have produced a Swiss cheese with large holes.
The planned transition period of five months gives tax evaders plenty of time to transfer funds from Switzerland to other tax havens.
Since foundations and trusts are not covered by the agreement, it is also sufficient to convert the assets stored in Switzerland into foundation assets.
corresponding forms are available at Swiss banks.
The tax authorities in Germany recently received information about several tax evaders who are hiding their assets in Switzerland.
The agreement now grants these individuals an amnesty, and the tax authorities are no longer allowed to use the information they have.
What kind of agreement is this that ties down the tax negotiations?
A promotional video for Swiss banks states that, as a result of this agreement, customers will continue to benefit even more from the values of the Swiss financial sector in the future.

This agreement is obviously lacking not only the necessary coordination at the EU level, but it also contradicts the EU's efforts to increase transparency in tax matters, to make tax collection more efficient in the member states, and above all to combat and prevent tax fraud.
Therefore, in our view, this cannot be acceptable.
We ask the EU to also take a strong stance against this in case of doubt.
Mr President, thank you very much. In accordance with the rules of procedure of our House and in consultation with the groups, I request the referral of this work back to the committees.
Madam President, I am pleased that we have succeeded in getting a sustainable, effective directive off the ground with Roberta Angelilli's report, and I would like to thank her for that.
The directive represents a significant step in the fight against child abuse.
However, we must not lose sight of one thing: the vast majority of crimes still occur within children's immediate social environment.
The perpetrators are found in families, schools, and social circles.
And here we are still at the beginning of our educational work.

That is why our children need to be empowered, strong enough to have the courage to confide in a trusted person in an emergency, but also strong enough to recognize dangers such as grooming when using the internet.
We must therefore work together to ensure that media literacy plays a greater role in the education of our children.
Education is of utmost importance here, as many teachers and parents are unaware of what their children can do with computers or mobile phones.
I believe there is a great need for catching up.

It is therefore to be welcomed that the present report also places great emphasis on prevention, since the authorities, as well as schools and families, must do everything in their power to prevent such heinous crimes from occurring in the first place.
As a result, the EU also needs better negotiation strategies with third countries, such as the USA and Russia.

Pages stored outside the EU can only be deleted effectively and quickly if we also work closely with these countries in the search for the perpetrators and jointly send out a clear signal against the condemnation of child sexual abuse.
Once the perpetrator has been caught, unfortunately, the legislator has often been surprisingly lenient in the past, suspending the majority of crimes on probation.
In future, the severity of the offence will be taken into greater account here.
Overall, however, it is important that the public debate continues, as the topic has a wide range of dimensions.

Prevention, victim protection, technical development, as well as extinguishing before blocking, legal proceedings, education, and intensive scientific documentation of the facts must continue to be advanced even after tomorrow's vote.
The fact is that we must by no means fold our arms and do nothing.
Rather, we must all accept the call to action, each of us, and ensure prevention and education.
Mr President, for years, the volume of the EU budget has remained at approximately the same level.
The EU's tasks have constantly expanded and the financial requirements have increased significantly.
Thus, necessary new institutions have been created for financial market supervision.
However, in order for these institutions to effectively carry out their tasks, they need to be well-funded.
As a result of the financial and banking crisis, the economic weaknesses of some EU member states have become undeniable.
To strengthen the economy of these countries, a comprehensive economic stimulus program would be necessary.
Some economic experts even speak of the need for a Marshall Plan for the crisis-ridden EU countries.
The EU does not need austerity programs that destroy growth, but rather a growth-promoting spending program that secures jobs and income for workers and young people in the EU.
But what is the Council doing in this situation?
It shortens the Commission proposal, which already falls far short of what is needed.

If a reasonable increase in the budget is not feasible in the current political climate, then Parliament and the Commission should do everything in their power to at least prevent the cuts proposed by the Council.
it is more difficult. Right now, in the crisis, it is becoming clear what kind of European Union we really want.
Do we want a Union where the glue is truly the idea that we say, "It is not indifferent to us whether people have to live in poverty in any Member State of the European Union"?
let us recognize our shared responsibility to fight against poverty and social exclusion.
Or do we opt for a union as outlined by colleagues from the far-right group in this Parliament?

Sometimes I believe that with the attitude of the member states and especially some governments of these member states, we are dangerously close to this vision of a European Union as formulated by the right-wing extremists.
just don't do anything together, don't use any common tools, don't set any common indicators, use vague wording wherever possible.
The third report makes this very clear on many issues, and I believe we need to become much stronger in this area.
What we need is an immediate halt to the sell-off of public assets, the sell-off of social security systems.
We need social and ecological minimum standards.
With winter approaching, it cannot happen again that people end up on the streets, are evicted, and ultimately freeze to death because of rising energy prices.
Here we share a common responsibility - the responsibility as the European Union.
We need to stand up for that, not for the nationalist nonsense we've heard from the right.
What advice would we have given to our colleagues in 1931 or 1938 when we were in depression, when the financial markets had already undermined the democracies and when we were heading towards war?
I think two things would be necessary - two emergency measures. We need something like a transitional government.
Do what you need to do, don't let yourself be slowed down, regulate every product, every institution, and every player like the woman
Mrs Merkel has said. But a transitional government alone, which enforces the fiscal emergency program, cannot have a future if there is no democratic emergency program.
That means in this case, of course we need a European community, of course we need other treaties, of course we need a system that works, but it only gains legitimacy if there are popular votes.

And we need to start campaigning now because the situation has become so dramatic that a complete change of thinking is necessary before the right-wingers, before the national dividers, regain control over something that was already built up.
Madam President. There is no doubt that this esteemed House is committed to transparency and openness towards the citizens.
Of course, my EPP group does that too.
But the present report goes far beyond the actual goal.
Existing legislation and interinstitutional agreements are ignored, and the protection of competitive processes, sensitive and personal data is disregarded.
This is a massive violation of data protection, which we are always so committed to defending elsewhere.
Should we now give up the privacy of the world public?
This is precisely the danger with the present report, because administrative procedures and decisions, which also include personnel issues for example, are to be published.
The same applies to the protection of trade secrets and sensitive information in the context of approval procedures, court proceedings and competition proceedings.

With its vague, unclear, and overly broad definitions, the report allows public access to such documents as well. This is because a document is defined as any data or content that is in any way related to the policies, measures, or decisions of any EU body or institution.
This also largely includes preparatory, confidential and secret documents, as well as all related information.
And so this definition encompasses not only documents, but also information.
Information from ongoing interinstitutional procedures, such as informal trilogue negotiations, must also be published.
Do you know, Mr. Rapporteur, what that really means?

It means public access to the proceedings, it means public influence on the decision-making process, then we might as well just bring in the lobbyists and let them negotiate. But does the citizen really want that?
I can't imagine it.
In addition, documents related to non-legislative procedures, measures of internal administrative organizations, etc., are also to be published. Where is the public interest in that?
or would it not rather hinder our work?
I think this report is not in the interests of our citizens.
It would bring about a flood of useless information.
He would make our work impossible, and above all, as you heard from the Commissioner, he is not acceptable to the other institutions because he violates the existing rules and laws.
You know that, Mr. Rapporteur, and basically, you are working against further transparency and against the citizens.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, on a topic as important and comprehensive as the White Paper on the future of transport, there is always a great risk of ending up with a Christmas tree, where everyone tries to accommodate their two or three preferred topics.
When you look at the result that will be put to a vote tomorrow, you can undoubtedly congratulate our rapporteur Mathieu Grosch.

He has managed to develop a good, coherent and manageable result from several hundred proposed amendments, which sets the main focus for the future of transport on safety, environmental protection, energy and technology.
I expressly welcome the fact that such important issues as the social health and labor law conditions of employees are adequately mentioned here.

This is particularly important in view of the impending shortage of skilled workers in the transport sector, which must be actively addressed if bottlenecks in well-trained professionals are to be prevented in the future.
Further opening up of cabotage in road transport only on the condition that social dumping and unfair conditions are prevented.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given an important place here.
The safety on our roads is an issue that we must continue to address in the future.
I have a more critical view of other points.
I would have liked a statement on the Shift model, where more traffic would be shifted from roads to rail and waterways.
For this reason, I do not think the discussion about the Giga-Aloners is the best solution for more sustainability.
Further liberalization of the railway sector and the opening up of national passenger transport should also be critically evaluated and reconsidered.
There are still technical harmonization and fair competition conditions to be resolved here.

But as I said, in this report I hope to express the expectations of Parliament in a way that is not just a pious wish list, but that by the year 2020 a goal will have been achieved and our proposals will have become a reality. Thank you very much.
My highly esteemed colleagues, it is only twenty years ago that the Central Asian states gained their state independence as a result of the collapse of the Soviet Union.
Coming from a dictatorship, the establishment of democratic and rule-of-law structures in these states remains a lasting challenge.
Nevertheless, these states are important trading partners of the EU and its member states due to their wealth of mineral resources and raw materials.
It is therefore only logical to regulate the EU's relations with these states within the framework of partnership and cooperation agreements.
Partnership and cooperation agreements are intended to promote collaboration and foster partnership-based actions, but not to lead to unilateral stigmatization.
Child labor, and especially forced child labor, is unfortunately still a widespread problem in many countries around the world that needs to be combated.

However, it should be noted that in many agriculturally dominated European regions, it was customary to extend the school holidays for children during harvest time and to give children from farming families the opportunity to help with the harvest, which no one would today describe as forced labor.
However, if there are signs of child forced labor in the cotton harvest in Uzbekistan, consequences must be drawn.

The same consequence must then apply to all other countries where child labor still exists, including those where we pursue economic interests of a completely different magnitude, such as in India or China.
We should not apply double standards here.

Mr President of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I can only join those in these ranks who have already offered their congratulations to the Presidency of the Council.
In difficult times, you were not only an honest broker, but you were also a European broker.
I think that was very comforting to feel in these difficult times, when we have political currents in a number of member states that suggest to people that one could achieve more alone than together.
They have placed the commonalities at the forefront.
It was also very refreshing to see that you have also found approval among the people in Poland in the domestic political debate with this clear European agenda.
That was not entirely easy in this context.
and also the highest respect for what you have achieved.
In the past six months, we have been able to make significant progress, particularly in the area of financial market regulation.

If I may single out one area of focus that I was able to negotiate myself, namely the issue of regulation for short selling and uncovered credit default swaps on government bonds, where the Commission has not dared to propose strict regulations, where everyone has told us

Member States were told that they would not prevail, and where it was possible, thanks to the Polish Presidency of the Council, to sanction such a highly speculative instrument and where it is necessary to also ban it in order to contribute to greater stability in the financial markets.

I would like to express my sincere thanks to your Minister of Finance and the Secretary of State, who have brought this about through a laborious discussion process between Parliament and the Council.
This is an example of what can be achieved together in the interests of security and stability in Europe.
Thank you very much, Mr. Vice President.
Since yesterday, the new surveillance mechanism for economic imbalances has been in effect.
In the meantime, the specific content regulations are also available.
Secondly, what development does the Commission now consider dangerous, and what economic problems does it want to see corrected?
The Commission considers an increase in unit labor costs in the Eurozone of more than three percent per year to be a problem.
A threshold value for falling wages, on the other hand, is not planned.
Cheap, dear Commission, does not automatically mean good.
It is not enough to train the member states to achieve prosperity at the expense of their trading partners.
Without investments in education, health, and energy efficiency, we can exploit our workers to the bone, but we won't be writing any economic success stories that way.
Another example from the Scoreboard: The loss of export market shares should be monitored and penalized.
That's nonsense.
As global trade increases, Europe's share statistically speaking inevitably decreases.
The indicator therefore penalizes countries that are already integrated into global trade.
That is why we believe the Commission should withdraw this scoreboard and overhaul it. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by joining in the thanks to our rapporteur and everyone who worked on the report, because it is not routine, even if one has to deal with competition policy for the fortieth time on the basis of a Commission report.

I must thank the Commissioner very much, because the year two thousand ten was the year in which you were fully responsible for competition policy for the first time, for the very comprehensive presentation.
However, I would like to make a request - you have just addressed this in your contribution - that we make some progress in the area of subsidies, particularly public subsidies in the banking sector.
should have come, because now, due to the new stress test by the European banking supervisor, a new capitalization in the banking sector is once again being demanded.
I don't believe that all of this contributes to the stability of the banking system, when on the one hand we still have a multitude of unanswered or unresolved legacy issues.
and in fact, new cases are already emerging as a result of the pressure being built up to increase the equity ratio, particularly in the area of private banks.

So, here is my truly urgent request, Commissioner, to reach a swift solution that also contributes to stabilizing the banking sector in such a way that it can also meet the challenges in the international environment.
The second major issue, diffusion control, will continue to be a pressing concern for us in the coming years.
Here, too, I can only urge the Commission to continue along the clear and transparent path it has taken so far in the context of merger control.
I believe that it is in the interest of all parties involved, especially consumers, that we ensure in the area of merger control that competition is also possible in larger or different structures.
With that in mind, I thank all those who have worked on this, and I hope, Commissioner, that we will soon reach a solution, particularly in the banking sector.

Commissioner, I believe you have just hit the nail on the head by jointly acknowledging that we are capable of launching a third industrial revolution in Europe if we realize that we can seize the opportunities for sustainability as an industrial opportunity.
Then you also spoke of resources, and that brings to mind a thought that I have completely forgotten about today.
I forgot about the human resources in my office.
Ms. Philipp, allow me to say that you have worked like a horse, achieving wonderful results. You were a key person in this matter.
I would like to express my gratitude for that.
Mr President, in order to ensure freedom of speech in Parliament, you also need a functioning microphone system.
My button for turning on the microphone has broken.
I would like to request that a technician restores freedom of speech.
Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues. It amazes me that we always have to remind ourselves what is actually meant by structural and cohesion policy.

Cohesion and structural policy is one of the central policy areas of the European Union, and it is defined to serve the strengthening of economic and social cohesion within the community, while particularly promoting growth and employment in underdeveloped regions.
The necessity and success of cohesion and structural policy have been proven, especially in the years of the crisis.
Many regions would face even greater challenges in terms of economic development if these funds were not available.
The implementation of Structural Funds support is based on operational programmes - as previously mentioned - which describe the support strategy for the respective region.
The European Union, Member States and regions are working together in partnership here, thereby creating genuine European added value.
The success of cohesion and structural policy is also based on the reliability of the programmes and the funds made available and allocated.

That is why I am very surprised when Member States, and also the Commission, as we are now seeing, repeatedly attempt to use the Structural Funds as a piggy bank for all sorts of current policy approaches.

This does not do justice to the sense and purpose of cohesion policy and, moreover, creates uncertainty for the actors in the regions who are already working on achieving the goals on the basis of long-term strategies and contracts.
Certainly, combating youth unemployment and promoting economic growth are important goals.

However, this will only be achieved if the partnership-based cooperation between the regions, the Member States and the Commission is maintained and the actors in the regions are involved and remain involved.
Because only you have the knowledge of what needs to be done in your regions.
Cohesion and structural policy is the unifying, partnership-based, and solidarity-driven bond of action between the individual policy levels in the European Union.
It makes the solidarity of Europe visible on the ground in the regions, and it should not be abandoned lightly due to political quick fixes.

Mr President, Commissioner, I support the compromise reached in the trialogue, which aims to strengthen the negotiating power of dairy farmers vis-Ã -vis the processing industry, although I am aware that it does not solve all the problems currently facing dairy farmers in some Member States.
As early as fifty years ago, Commissioner Mantzolt had provided preferential measures for the creation of producer associations as part of the CAP.
In my country, Luxembourg, the dairy industry is the main pillar of our agriculture due to the high proportion of grassland.
Our farmers have long understood that the best solution is to join together in a cooperative that handles milk processing itself.
Five member states voted against the compromise in the Council for precisely this reason, as it does not meet its requirements as a soft landing instrument.

The European Commission has the right of initiative when it comes to legislative proposals, which is why I would like to urge you to submit a legislative proposal to the Council and the European Parliament in 2012 to correct this obvious and costly error in the system.

A linear reduction in the superlevy by 2015, which is applied to each kilo of milk delivered, or the abolition of the fat correction, could at least mitigate the negative effects of the expiring regulation without harming the unaffected member states.
However, the present milk package is also intended as a final report by the High Level Group, which aims to ensure a smooth transition when milk quotas are phased out.
It is astonishing that milk quotas are not mentioned at all in this report.
The young and ambitious farmers in Luxembourg and four other member states, who are trying to prepare for the liberalization of the milk market and expand their production,
In order to be able to compete in the global market after 2015, they can only do so by buying additional quotas now, just before the end of the milk quota system.
a huge additional and unnecessary capital expenditure that puts you at a disadvantage compared to your colleagues in the twenty-two member states. Thank you.
So, there you go, Bibelukat. A question. Are you aware that we have had Community Bonds for a long time now?
and that the resolution does not speak about Euro Bonds in general, but rather about very different options.
And are you aware that not all of these options require a contract amendment?
I find it questionable that you have once again separated generalities about Euro Bonds here.
And precisely the level of detail that we have achieved here with Mrs Goulart's good proposal, we should not abandon again.
I would like to hear a bit more differentiation in your statements and am curious to hear what you have to say about it.
I just want to say briefly, dear colleague Goulart, that this is not an evaluation I have made here.
I just want to point out that the last Italian government bond before Italy joined the euro had a yield of ten percent.
And there was no outcry in Italy, and no one said that other countries should now take over.
It was self-evident that one had to pay high interest rates.

And now suddenly, because we have had ten years of low interest rates and have become excessively indebted, because money has become cheap for investments as well as for public spending, we want to prolong this through Euro Bonds.
This is a trap we can't get out of, and I stand by that.
Mr President, Commissioner, your answer has really rather disappointed me.

They obviously want to stick to the old system, where complicated negotiations have to be conducted per country and where, in turn, no further access to literature is granted, meaning that no additional opportunities are created for the blind and visually impaired.
This is all the more sad for me because the European Union is now blocking a step forward in the WIPO, while all the other contracting parties would be willing to move forward.
A huge opportunity is being missed here.

You are not fighting here for more rights for authors, but against people to whom the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities should guarantee equal access to cultural goods and that they can also participate fully in these cultural goods.
I appeal to you: please dismantle barriers and agree to a binding contract.

Madam President, dear colleagues. The discussion here in this House shows that we actually represent the entire spectrum: on the one hand, those who want no restrictions at all, and on the other hand, those who associate every form of immigration with the threat of mass immigration.
These are the two extremes within this house.
I believe that family reunification must be considered with great reason and rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed problems in member states where measures are taken that are too restrictive.
because family reunification cannot be burdened with so many obstacles that in the end no one can be reunited.
On the other hand, it is entirely justified that member states demand language skills, that they demand integration, but also that they demand a willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, the Member States naturally have the right to articulate the problems that arise in family reunification, and we should not push these issues aside.
