If countries like Greece or Malta or even Romania or Italy are no longer allowed to articulate the problems they have in this context, then I no longer know if we are democratic if we simply ignore problems.
I don't think we need another directive just yet
We should discuss the problems carefully and then think about how we can eliminate them.
The constant re-production of guidelines does not lead to an improvement of the guidelines and their implementation.
We currently have some implementation problems.

However, I also fully understand that we must first come to terms with the fact that we should not be creating a new directive and adding to it before we have thoroughly discussed the issues of the old directive in any way.
I am in favor of listening to the member states and at the same time respecting the fundamental right to family reunification.
If one does this with reason and understanding, then I also believe that we will find a good path.
Mr President, "think before you think," advises the Polish aphorist StanisÅaw JÃ¼rgelewicz, and this recommendation would do us good in this Parliament at times.
A few weeks after the resolution on the Central Asia strategy was adopted in this House, in which the Central Asian states were censured, strike events are now also taking place in Jarnao Zend.
reflecting on the situation in Kazakhstan, without waiting for the results of the ongoing investigations, which are being carried out with international participation.
As much as the dead are to be lamented, and the injured and detained have the right to an investigation of the events that followed, the background remains unclear.

Even Vladimir Koslov, chairman of the unregistered opposition party ALGA, said, "That was a group of other people. The unrest is not in the interest of the strikers, because it only provides a reason to take violent action against them."
The Central Asia expert Arkadi Dubnov also said, "It is not impossible that parts of the Kazakh opposition living abroad will also get involved."
On the other hand, however, it could well fit someone's agenda in the Kazakh capital Astana to maintain the tensions.
After all, the power elite in Kazakhstan are already fighting over the succession of President Nursultan Nazarbayev.
We had the opportunity to speak with the Kazakh opposition in the presence of the Kazakh ambassador here in Parliament.

UN Special Envoy Miroslav Jenszak announced today that he is impressed by the Kazakh government's attention to the events of Jana Ozen, and that it is necessary to uncover the true background of the UN.
We should take the Kashmiri authorities at their word, judge them by their actions, but not resort to knee-jerk condemnations.
If I understood you correctly, the statement you made today is: Yes, the Commission is fighting for the continuation of the food program for the most needy people in the European Union.
She will do everything to present concrete ideas in the foreseeable future, including where the program will be located and how it will be financed.
I believe this is urgently necessary and think that we share the responsibility of ensuring that this food program actually becomes a reality.
not because I consider it the ultima ratio, but because in my view it is a signal to show people that we still have a basic sense of the necessary solidarity with those in need.

the living conditions of people in the European Union who, unfortunately, have not been able to participate in development and have become the first and greatest victims of the way the European Union has fought the crisis.
I am thinking here of Greece, I am thinking of Spain, I am thinking of other countries where exactly what we do as the European Union primarily harms the poorest, the poor.
We are setting an example, but unfortunately it is no longer enough.
I therefore think that it is urgently necessary that we do not only consider the eighteen million people in the European Union who are currently dependent on food aid.

It is not about making resources available, but rather that we must prioritize this issue. We want to put the fight against poverty back on the top of our agenda, or even place it there for the first time.
We have not conveyed this signal so far.

But in my view, this is the crucial point if we want to make progress here and if we also want to gain the trust of the citizens of our European Union that we are indeed creating a social and solidaristic Union.
In that sense, you have our support.
We ourselves, dear colleagues, are also called upon to do something to ensure that the governments that have been blocking progress must abandon this attitude.
I think that's also a piece of self-commitment for us.
Dear Mr. Daul, I have listened to you attentively.
What you are proposing, namely to introduce a growth test for all expenditure in parallel with the subsidiarity test, effectively means narrowing down the objectives to growth.
I would like to know how you reconcile that with the principles of a Christian Democratic faction, which surely still recognizes goals beyond growth.
It must be common knowledge that the economy cannot give birth to children, raise them, or enable them to live in an intact natural environment.
This suggests that the priorities need to be changed by the Commission and also by the Council, that they need to be reconsidered.
As a group, we will carefully examine whether what you presented this morning actually corresponds to a change in priorities.
Until now, the motto has been: First the economy, which needs functioning financial markets.
The initial focus was on stabilizing public finances, reducing debt, and keeping the markets calm.
Mr. Dohl, who unfortunately is not present right now, I just wanted to say that I would keep it the same as Georges Machet.
Although I didn't understand his answer, I would disagree with him.
I think the measures that have been introduced were simply wrong.
They were not right, it was not right, to focus solely on the economic recovery and completely ignore what was happening to the people.
It was not right to prioritize the stability of the euro above all else and to say, "What happens to the people is completely irrelevant to us."
It must be the other way around. First, it's about the people, and then we can continue to talk about the Euro stabilization.

The speculative attacks on Spain pushed the interest rates for Spanish government bonds above six percent and thus also close to the interest rate level at which other countries such as Greece, Portugal, or Ireland sought support from the rescue fund.
The austerity policies imposed on member states by the EU, the ECB, and also by the IMF, with drastic reductions in all types of public spending.
Lowering wages and pensions, increasing VAT and much more has simply placed the burden on citizens and has not prevented a new spiral of austerity.
Rigorous cuts in state spending exacerbate the downturn, drive up the national debt ratio, and this must be our shared understanding.
When Mr Draghi recently said that the European social model is finished, I am pleased, Mr Barroso, that you say 'No, we in the Commission do not think like that'.
Then I also expect you to go to Greece, to send your people to Greece and to Portugal, to Ireland, and to carefully document what happens there.
What happens to people who are currently struggling to survive?
What is happening or what are we doing together to finally interrupt this suicide spiral that has just begun in the most affected debt countries?
We can't just stand by and watch this happen.
And we are of no benefit from socio-political programs that will work at some point in the future, when other measures have already taken effect.
We need to act now. Where are your 2020 strategy objectives for combating poverty?
What has become of the European Anti-Poverty Platform?
It has been set aside.
That was before the crisis.
But now, in the midst of the crisis, people need help, they need support, and they need the European Union to take action.
You don't need empty promises.
We need concrete ideas about what should be done now.
If you do that, you will receive support from my group.
Support all those who have recognized the signs of the times within the Commission and want to change things.
But please don't just carry on like this and say that it will all work out.
It will be too late if things continue like this. I urge you to present a concrete project, a concrete program, on how we can now actively help the people in the affected countries.
Do something about it.
We will have to do this in our countries so that the funds for the ESF are not blocked, so that the funds for the ESF are not cut in 2013 or 2014 to 2020, or indeed for the other programmes.
that the Member States fulfil their responsibilities.
Dear colleagues, the current state of public finances and the economy in Europe leaves no room for a fairy tale about tax policy.
The situation in the Council is quite simple: little progress is being made on tax policy proposals.
Why?
because some countries are against further tax cooperation.
They benefit from aggressive tax planning, they are tax havens themselves.
And the treaties clearly state unanimity in tax matters.
That is why the EU Commission has repeatedly suffered setbacks with its proposals in the past.
They are watered down, they do not move forward, as with the interest rate directive, and in the case of more recent proposals, nothing ambitious has been suggested out of preemptive obedience.

Therefore, Mr. Schemeter, I ask you, I know your job is not an easy one in this regard. Change the strategy, propose strict measures, and then rely on increased cooperation to end the blockade position in the Council.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the present proposal on risk-sharing instruments will certainly not be able to prevent a state bankruptcy where it is likely to occur.
But doing something is still better than doing nothing at all.
Extraordinary situations sometimes require extraordinary measures.

The budget and debt crisis in some states has led to such an extraordinary situation that important projects and measures within the framework of cohesion and structural policy can no longer be implemented because the banking sector is no longer available as a financier and private investors are no longer available.
I consider the proposal to create risk-sharing instruments for the continued financing of projects in structural policy to be an extraordinary measure.
The means of cohesion and structural policy available to countries that wish to use these division instruments can be used to provide financial security for projects already underway.

I am very grateful to the rapporteur, Danuta HÃ¼bner, for her significant contribution to clarifying the Commission's proposal and for once again clearly outlining when and how these instruments should be used.
However, I also believe that these risk-sharing instruments must only be due to the current situation and cannot set a precedent for the future funding period.
When the last amendment to the regulation on biometric passports in the year two thousand nine called for a review after three years and the submission of four studies, our group supported it.
and also because she had repeatedly raised major concerns for data protection reasons and also because of the overestimation of the benefits of biometric data in travel passports.
The belief in perfect identification, the overestimation of this method, and what follows from it, as well as the underestimation of other links in the security chain, are truly problematic.
The handling of biometric data is still subject to this major misconception, namely the assumption that it is unchangeable and most trustworthy.
That is, by no means, the case.
These data are also modifiable over the course of a person's life.
In children, they look different than in old age.
And that is also why reliable and serious studies and conclusions drawn from them are necessary.
Counterfeiting continues apace.
We have now been able to determine that.
As repeatedly demonstrated in Britain and other countries, the chips are not at all secure against misuse.
They are broken cheerfully and can cause lasting damage to those affected.
Standards within the EU are also extraordinarily diverse.
The error rate is very high, as in France and the Netherlands.
The question must be asked repeatedly: what good are biometric data to us if documents are being forged and are in circulation?
So if one link in the chain is forged, the original documents are inconsistent, biometric data would not help us further.
The Chaos Computer Club in Germany needed only a few minutes to demonstrate a forgery.

To do this, the friends from the Chaos Computer Club needed the lid of a plastic bottle, a second-hand adhesive, a digital camera, and a bit of wood glue. In just a few minutes, they had cracked the chip. That's all there is to the so-called security.
We expect the Commission to present the studies and, of course, also the results and the consequences that follow from them. Thank you.
Esteemed Council, unfortunately, the Commission is not as adequately represented today as I would have wished, out of respect for Parliament.

As a representative from a region that is massively affected by the planned changes, namely the Eiffel region, after carefully following the debate, I am left wondering whether the unfortunately only marginally viable attempt

whether a standardization of the criteria for disadvantaged areas really meets the needs of these regions, especially since the necessary information is not available for a meaningful and responsible decision.
Above all, I wonder whether a sufficient impact assessment was really carried out.
To do justice to farmers, we need not only biophysical criteria, but also socio-economic criteria.

Therefore, I urge the Commission to reconsider this important aspect with the necessary time, detached from the overall package of CAP reform, and above all after the submission of the necessary documents and a careful analysis of the impacts, based on the criteria.
I do believe that we must work on this, in cooperation with the Asylum Support Office and the Greek authorities, to more quickly identify which persons who have come to Greece may actually be...

They can also be transferred to other countries in the European Union because, firstly, they can never return to their home country and, secondly, they may have potential and qualifications that can be beneficial for everyone.
However, essentially, it is also about helping the Greeks to facilitate registration and identification more quickly, in order to expedite the aid processes.

to return to their home countries those who neither have the qualifications nor the right to stay in Greece or the European Union, because they would have been able to remain in their own home countries.
Thank you, Mr President, Mr Minister, Commissioner, and also thank you to the rapporteur for her always very committed and exemplary work.
I can share much of the criticism that Sophie Infeld has expressed, support this, or have also supported this in part.
But then there always comes a point at which one must take responsibility.
And for the EPP, or for myself, I therefore also maintain that we must now deal with the realities and cannot retreat to ideological or theoretical positions.
The fact is, the US has been collecting this PNR data for ten years, and there hasn't been a single complaint.
The fact is that we all do not want the data traffic to stop, even if we are opposed to it and believe that we can stop the data traffic altogether.
They had just carried that out.
The fact is that we do not want air traffic between Europe and the USA to come to a standstill.
And the fact is that the USA has a right to know who is coming into their country.
And the fact is, in my opinion, that the legal services have all told us verbally that this agreement is better than the other agreement, than the alternatives.
That is why one must also take responsibility here.
And that's what we were elected for.
Responsibility for the citizens, whom one would otherwise leave alone with less protection and rights.
responsibility for the airlines, which would otherwise be left in absolute legal uncertainty, the Commissioner had also pointed out.
Responsibility also for the EU as a contracting party in matters of data protection and security, but also responsibility for a balanced relationship between security and data protection.
That is why, all in all, even considering that this agreement is not perfect, we are in favor of agreeing to this agreement in the end.
If you want to better protect citizens and provide them with better data protection, you take on this responsibility and agree to this agreement. Thank you.
Mr President, Commissioner. Those were insightful remarks you gave us.
Thank you very much for that.

Figures sometimes speak louder than big words, and to this day, the European Parliament - you also mentioned this - and the European Patent Office have granted nearly two patents for plants and almost twelve patents for animals, which were developed with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I would like to mention two outstanding examples: the approval of patents on genetically modified and selectively bred barley, which applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
This is why our farmers, brewers, producers, and consumers are all affected.
And this example, in my opinion, shows a devastating extent of patenting.
Second example: do not confuse the so-called long-life tomato with the long-life oil you have in your diesel engines.
This patent was obtained using a trick by the US corporation Arcadia, which bypassed the valid EU regulations.
It is not the tomato that has been patented, but its genetic material, specifically selected enzymes.

This shows the trick being used here and that, although, as you said, Commissioner, it is clearly stated in Article 4 of the 1988/91 Directive on the legal protection of biotechnological inventions that plant varieties and animal breeds a and b are not patentable, they are essentially biological processes for the breeding of plants or animals.
We believe that this definition needs to be clarified, it needs to be interpreted more precisely.
Technical procedures used to support conventional breeding should not lead to patentability as a whole.
We specifically do not patent life.
And we need a clear signal here for more ethics and more honesty in dealing with creation, once again against the patentability of life throughout Europe.
Therefore, Commissioner, we demand a clear statement from the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are and will remain prohibited in Europe.
Secondly, we demand a clear stance on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive: no patents on life.
Thirdly, Commissioner, on behalf of many farmers and breeders in Europe, we demand a clear establishment of the breeder and farmer privilege throughout all legislation. Thank you.
Madam President, I would like to comment on the dismissal of Europol and Eurojust.
Regarding Europol: There is little to no criticism here.

The annual financial statements reflect the financial situation in the year 2010 in all material respects, and all transactions underlying them are in accordance with regulations and therefore also lawful.
The only thing that stands out is the high transfers in relation to the overall low initial costs.
Europol attributes this to the move to a new headquarters, which is of course understandable.
But Europol says it will take further measures in the future to avoid such high transfers.
In addition, Europol intends to commit to monthly monitoring of the budget execution from the year 2012 onwards.
I recommend that we follow up on this to see if it actually happens.
Against this background, I recommend granting Europol discharge.
Eurojust: The annual accounts also reflect the financial situation in 2010 in all material respects.
All transactions are also lawful and compliant here.
But here too, high operating expenses were carried over to 2011.
According to Eurojust, this was mainly due to an organizational structure project for a new computer infrastructure and costs associated with data processing.
It is announced that all of this will be improved in the future, and that tender requirements will also be better adhered to.
I also recommend that we review this in the future and, above all, check whether all open positions will actually be filled in the future.
That has been improved.
But if these positions are not filled soon, we would have to consider cutting funds, and that would be negative for AURIUS.
I still recommend discharge.
Madam President, most esteemed Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what should fill us with anxiety and panic is not the sheer number of unemployed young people in Europe alone, but the trend.
From 2008 to 2011, the number of young unemployed people increased by 6.25%, according to the International Labour Organization.
It is this development that urgently requires measures. We are not only disconnecting an entire generation from the job market, we are disconnecting an entire generation from a livable future.
If we give young people the feeling of absolute uselessness, we should not be surprised that young people are turning away from this EU because they have no reasonable work and life prospects.

Commissioner, I urgently request that you ensure that decisive countermeasures are initiated. I already recognize some progress, but please make sure that the long-standing mental stagnation does not now turn into operational haste.

When I read that the Commission is launching a program under which young people applying abroad are now to receive financial support, then we are organizing a traveling circus that does not solve the problem.
On the contrary, it becomes counterproductive, as technicians, doctors, engineers, and nursing staff are then lured away by richer states that are not in this crisis.
What is needed now, in this crisis that is the cause of this development, are offensive measures, namely the dismantling of this austerity madness that is crippling the economy in Europe.
We need a targeted growth policy, we need to strengthen domestic purchasing power, public investment in education, research, and alternative energies.
That would be the way.
By combining it with European funding, it would then be possible to actually develop an integrated concept that provides young people with a life perspective.
This youth unemployment is also incompatible with the nonsense of wanting to raise the retirement age for people to seventy.
We need a different policy that gives young people access to the job market.
Therefore, I urgently ask for your thanks.
Colleague, you just said that everything that would speak in favor of the financial transaction tax is speculation, and then you came up with very speculative examples yourself.

I would like to know from you what you think of these Commission investigations, in light of what you have said, which very, very clearly states that up to now, the real economy and its dependence on have been far too little considered by mistake.

This shows the financial markets that 95% of companies are by no means dependent on borrowing money and that it is indeed possible to turn the negative growth effect that has been discussed into a positive one by making appropriate public investments that promote growth.
Is this just speculation for you, or would you say that such a well-founded, broad-ranging study by the Commission also has its justification and represents a strong argument?

Ladies and gentlemen, the financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been under discussion for many years, but I believe it incorporates essential elements of the Tobin tax.
It at least takes up the idea of involving the financial markets in taxation and, above all, in the costs of the crisis.
I think that is a very important signal to the financial markets.
But this is also a very important signal to the citizens, to our voters.
In a number of member countries, there were numerous actions, petitions, and written appeals to politicians to finally introduce a financial transaction tax at the European level.
I think that the Parliament has achieved a great success with the majority that has indicated its support for this report on this tax.
Certainly, this is not enough to stabilize and limit the financial markets, as might be necessary, but I think it is a truly important step that has been taken here.
I would like to expressly appeal to the Council to take the voices of citizens and voters seriously and to work towards this goal.
that there will be a real introduction, that the introduction of this tax will not be blocked in the Council due to the British position or other positions.
I think it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax, and I think it is a great responsibility.

It is now up to the Council to take action, and I would like to use my speaking time to appeal to the Council to do everything in its power to ensure that this tax is actually implemented and becomes a reality.
Madam President, dear colleagues, I believe that despite all the detailed issues that can be discussed and will be addressed further in the legislative process, we should agree on one thing:
This is clear. Financial markets cannot function according to this model. When everything goes well, the banks pocket the profits, and when something goes wrong, the taxpayers foot the bill.
And that is why it makes sense to subject financial transactions to a tax.
And it makes sense to do this across borders.

In Europe, or at least in the Eurozone, we would not have disruptions, but rather we would make a lasting contribution to creating a stable financial center that generates what financial centers are actually intended for, namely that companies

Having access to capital means that savers have the opportunity to put something aside or set it aside for retirement, and that the financial markets can once again fulfill the purpose for which they were created, namely to provide added value for the real economy.
What drove us into the financial crisis were products that created no value for the real economy.

That is why it makes sense to contribute through taxation to ensure that this is heavily punished, that it is sanctioned, that it is controlled, in the sense that capital once again fulfills its role.
That is why I am advocating for this proposal to be adopted today by a large majority.
The reform of the general preferential system was indeed necessary.
It is good now that there are longer repayment periods and that there is more security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too imprecise, as the Development Committee has already pointed out.
Unfortunately, the Commission only refers to the World Bank classification.
In the past, Parliament has repeatedly expressed strong criticism of the gross domestic product as the sole criterion.
The definition of upper-middle-income countries can refer to countries with four to twelve dollars in gross domestic product.
So that is a huge and far too wide a range, and it does not do justice to the realities on the ground in any way.
We certainly do not find it problematic that countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are dropping out.
The reform in this regard was therefore good.
But these countries are high-income countries anyway.
Russia and China are upper-middle-income countries, and we certainly don't have to worry about them falling out of the APS.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer countries, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
Up until now, the Commission had at least also taken into account the vulnerability criterion, i.e., countries that export little or only very few goods.
This at least prevents countries that are less dependent on exporting products and are therefore very vulnerable from being rated too high.
Why, then, did the Commission highlight this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, Fiji, Gabon, and Botswana, for example, will thus be excluded, even though their economies fall under the criterion of vulnerability.
Why didn't the Commission continue with the old criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate anyway?
There is a growing suspicion that the Commission wants to force poorer countries into unfavorable free trade agreements.

The preference system, however, is an instrument for promoting development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments, in which the development path of a country or region no longer plays any role at all.
Fortunately, however, the Members in the plenary will still have the opportunity to approve our amendment, which includes vulnerability as a criterion.
However, the new regulation also leads to trade regions being torn apart.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to follow different rules when exporting to the EU.
This has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
The Commission should focus more on developing regions rather than individual countries.
Here too, we Greens have submitted an amendment, which we hope will receive a lot of support.
It is also problematic when countries that have benefited from the APS until yesterday are suddenly dropped from the program overnight.
Transition periods are necessary, and we see in our own countries that a few months are not enough for economic development.

Ultimately, however, we Members of Parliament must also consider whether we want to focus solely on speed for all legislative initiatives and then work with lopsided compromises, or whether we would rather involve the entire plenary session.

I believe that the entire parliament is important for legislation, as is democracy, and it is not time or speed that is important, but rather it takes time and democracy to do this and to pass laws properly. Thank you very much.

Mr President, High Representative, I was also a member of the European Parliament's election observation mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo and was able to witness the hope and expectation for a better future that people had as they stood and waited at the polling stations to cast their vote.
We know today that these expectations were not met.
Although the Congo calls itself democratic, these elections were not fair or democratic.
We must address this issue head-on, as my colleague Mrs Nedelcheva has done in her report.
The previous president, Joseph Kabila, has declared himself the winner of the election. The opposition is being suppressed.
In the east of the country, violent clashes between government troops and so-called rebels have flared up again, and it is unclear whether third countries like Rwanda are involved.
The civilian population is the one that suffers in every case, and has not been able to live in peace and quiet for decades now.
The country's wealth is squandered in a swamp of corruption, leaving the Congo at the bottom of all international rankings.

The international community of states, and particularly the European Union with its capabilities, must increase the pressure on the President of the Republic of Congo to allow for genuine democracy in his country. He has an opportunity to do so in the next regional elections.
and that the Congolese army does not harass the civilian population, but finally takes international fugitives for crimes against humanity like Bosco and Daganga and brings them to justice.
Internationally, all states should finally commit to no longer supplying any more weapons to the Congo.
Without external pressure, human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Madam President, the Tupac is intended to create additional enforcement rights against crisis countries in the Eurozone.
The European Semester, which was established as a framework for necessary and improved coordination of financial and economic policy, is to be given teeth.
According to the Commission's wishes, member states should be forced to accept financial aid.
The Six-Pack has already established extensive sanctioning possibilities that can be imposed on Eurozone countries with financial problems.
The European Semester is already being perceived by citizens more as a dismantling of democracy than as a sensible economic policy coordination instrument.
At the same time, the German government is openly threatening Greek citizens with expulsion from the Eurozone if they make the wrong decision in Sunday's election.
Why don't we stop these humiliating and undemocratic threats?
In a situation where the Euro crisis has once again dramatically escalated, I think of Spain, of Cyprus, it does not help us to publicly shame member states that are in crisis.
We should finally develop solutions. The Tupac rapporteurs have developed some very sensible approaches to this end.
Elisa Ferreira did indeed mention the debt relief fund. This would be a worthwhile and sensible measure to combat debt.
Or perhaps Jean Paul Gauzet's proposal for an orderly state bankruptcy.
However, it is crucial that Europe makes a joint and solidaric effort to put the Eurozone back on a growth path.
The strong countries in Europe must stop being complacent and pointing fingers at their partner countries.
You need to start doing your homework, invest in growth, and take responsibility.
The one-sided austerity policy Ã  la Merkel has simply failed as a solution to the crisis.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in June 2010, the EU heads of state and government finally realised that the European Community needs a more coordinated financial and economic policy.
At the summit, you essentially invented the European Semester.
It is absolutely correct that members of an economic and monetary union cannot solely focus on how their policies affect businesses, workers, and consumers in their own country.
A European perspective is necessary.
An internal market without coordination in economic, wage, and social policy presents a great temptation for member states to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbors.
Such imbalances can economically, but also politically, bring the monetary union to its knees.
The EU is currently facing exactly such a situation.

For years, the German economy has been draining the lifeblood from its neighbors; instead of providing stimulus through investment and wage growth, Berlin has brought the Eurozone to the brink of ruin with a decade of aggressive export policies.
That is why it is encouraging that the Commission is slowly getting to grips with this core problem of the Euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and is making corresponding suggestions.

The Federal Republic is quite rightly being called upon to invest more in education, research and childcare, and the Commission is quite rightly being called upon to stop the misuse of mini-jobs and to align wage growth with productivity growth.
This is a late, but important realization.
I hope, Commissioner, Mr Rehn, that you will vigorously advocate this demand to the German government, even if there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, esteemed colleagues. First of all, I would like to express my gratitude to the Commission, especially Commissioner Barnier, for the simple reason that the experiences from the last legislative period, two thousand and nine,

was happened was that, with the exception of a very brief moment of awakening when the proposal for the European private company came up, Mr Barnier's predecessor, Commissioner McCreevy, effectively put company law to sleep. We in these five years of this important issue, which is also significant for the internal market,
have progressed.
Fortunately, that has fundamentally changed.

In the meantime, there are a variety of consultation documents from the European Commission, an expert group that has been working on the issue of further developing company law, and we now have a brand new consultation that we, as a Parliament, are naturally also addressing.
The Legal Committee has decided that we do not want to do this in the form of a report, simply because a report would require additional time and, of course, would also be somewhat more detailed.

We have chosen the method of an oral question to the Commission in order to be able to discuss this issue with the Commission, with Commissioner Barnier, and at the same time to make clear in a subsequent resolution our position as Parliament on what should happen now.
I believe that it is necessary to develop a new action plan for European company law, similar to the one we had about ten years ago, and for many reasons.
There are gaps within European company law, real gaps, which basically mean that the single market is not complete.
I would like to mention, as an example, the absence of the fourteenth directive on seat relocation, which, in my opinion, is a very typical example of such a gap.
Parliament has twice called in legislative initiative reports for the European Commission to come up with concrete proposals on this matter.
There is also the expert panel appointed by the European Commission itself, which has also expressed the same opinion.
It is simply one of the fundamental freedoms in the internal market that a company must be able to move within the internal market, including with regard to its registered office.
This possibility does not exist today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

However, against this backdrop, I must also criticize the fact that the European Commission's statement on the 14th Directive so far actually falls well short of Parliament's expectations and, in our opinion, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
But we are confident that, in the course of further work, if the action plan is implemented, this proposal will hopefully be included in the action plan.
Another important point in corporate law is the question of the further development of corporate law with the aim of reducing burdens for companies.
We already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table here, for example on the topic of
But I believe there is also more to be done and there are further aspects that will be clarified during the consultation.
We are also expecting further proposals from the Commission here.
I would also like to ask the Commission to revive the issue of the European Private Company, which is currently stuck in the Council.
If there are individual member states in the EU that, due to a lack of their own decision-making power, are not able to resolve the deadlock on their own,

If we want to move Europe forward, then we must consider using the instrument of enhanced cooperation, as we have done with other initiatives such as patents and family law, so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to benefit from this possibility.
I would ask the Commission to give this issue some more thought.
Another open issue is the question of applicable law, i.e. a kind of Rome regulation for cross-border problems in company law.
I also believe that this issue requires further investigation and discussion, and I would ask the Commission to do so.
This is also closely related to
We have the insolvency law, but it has been announced anyway that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission in the foreseeable future.
You see, there is a huge amount of work to be done in corporate law.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has taken the initiative here once again and that it is clear that we will receive significant proposals in the second half of this legislative period, which can also represent progress in shaping the internal market.
Parliament supports this in principle and in approach.
We will certainly need to discuss the details.
But for that, I also need to thank the Commission.
Of course, we would be pleased if the Commission were to actually take up our initiatives and convert them into concrete proposals.
Dear Commissioner, I greatly appreciate your proposal regarding productivity-oriented wage policy.
But you cut a deal with Mrs. Merkel on the minimum wage, and I don't believe you about the question of job creation in the healthcare sector.
How is new work supposed to be created there when the Commission has already forced southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by up to half?

How can employment in the healthcare sector grow if, in the new country-specific recommendations for the European Semester, the Commission is forcing some member states to further reduce their healthcare spending?
I fear this point in this plan is merely announcement politics, not a real initiative for new jobs.
On the contrary, due to austerity measures, there is already a shortage of medical supplies and medications, not just in Greece.
I think that those who are constantly setting up new bailouts for banks must now work towards a bailout for the people, especially for securing medical care in the crisis countries. Thank you.
The mood among unfortunate pro-Europeans like myself is one of frightened horror at what is currently happening in Europe.
It is, after all, encouraging that it is now being stated much more clearly what we are dealing with, and that Italy is not being ignored either.

You know yourselves that you are caught in a series of traps, not only in the trap of debt and growth, but also in the trap of trust and the trap of power, esteemed Commission and also to the Council.
Unfortunately, they have so far failed to actually address the central issue of the financial sector's detachment from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here is repeatedly evaluated in expert opinions as no serious limits have been set on the shadow banking system.
Furthermore, we are dealing with systemic risks, the issue of "too big to fail" has not been adequately addressed, and there is little need to say anything about the rating agencies.
As you prepare for the summit, I can only urge and advise you to restore credibility in Europe by seriously addressing the issue of power between the real economy and the financial sector.
In short, you must finally work credibly with the Europeans to ensure that the banks are brought under control and that the citizens are not always left to bear the burden.

Mr. Colleague FÃ¤rm, you come from a country that has rejected the euro, but presumably with the central argument that one wants to retain the flexibility of devaluation, especially for socio-political reasons.
In light of the experiences you have now had in Sweden, would you recommend that the Greeks also leave the Eurozone in order to be able to actively use this socio-political instrument of devaluation?
Thank you very much, Mr President. I would also like to express my sincere thanks to the shadow rapporteurs and to the rapporteur.
We adopted this report in the Environment Committee with a substantial majority, with sixty-two votes in favor, zero votes against, and no abstentions.
This shows that we are actually very closely aligned there, including when it comes to compromises.

And of course, the top priority in this legislative process must be a high level of protection, a high level of consumer protection, especially for the most vulnerable members of our society, for children who need protection.
When it comes to gluten intolerance, this is a problem, especially in kindergartens.
If you take a look around, I have two children of this age, and considering the prevalence of allergies and intolerances there, I believe we were in the right place.
We should then also discuss this with the Council and the Commission during the second reading.
I think that we will then also arrive at a good result.

Mr. President, a report about a traffic accident over the weekend involving an HGV driver who fell asleep from exhaustion and drove into the ditch has once again confirmed to me how necessary it is to
clear and consistent regulation of driving and rest periods and their monitoring using a digital tachograph is important for us, for road safety, and also for the people affected themselves.
The digital tachograph represents a certain innovation. It has new problems, but also old ones.
The new problems arise from new manipulation possibilities, which we also need to control technically.
The old problems are those that we can observe, so to speak, in the control or lack of control in various member states.
In my view, what we are now regulating anew must take into account, first and foremost, that not every time when no journey is recorded automatically results in a rest period.
Because many drivers have to load and unload, and this is naturally also considered working time.
The second problem is that the speed records have been removed from the file.
I think that's wrong, because there are also major accident risks here.
We also want to have weight sensors, and we also want to have a hotline to report fraud, which is anonymous and can be traced.
What I will also be bringing forward is a motion that animal transport control be included in this regulation.
I think this is important because it must also be a central element of our legislation.

Madam President, many people could still be alive today or would not have any lasting disabilities if professional medical help had been provided quickly after their accident, that is, within the first so-called "golden hour".
We would be a significant step closer to Vision Zero.
Well, the eCall system we are discussing today cannot prevent accidents. It also does not absolve anyone of the duty to provide first aid.
It is only used to automatically inform an emergency response center in the event of a serious accident.
It must also establish linguistic contact with the accident vehicle to prevent abuse and overloading due to minor accidents.
Emergency doctors are only sent to the accident site once the emergency call has been confirmed or if no one responds, equipped with a few, but life-saving pieces of information.
The responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain lies subsidiarily with the Member States.
As long as the sensors installed in the vehicle do not detect an accident, the eCall system remains dormant, meaning it does not send any signals or data and cannot be located.
From a data protection perspective, it is therefore far superior to a mobile phone.
The system only becomes active when it is automatically awakened by sensors or manually triggered consciously.
It then sends an agreed-upon minimum set of information to an emergency operations center.
Europe-wide uniform standards and specifications will ensure that this data is recognized, evaluated, and handled upon arrival as an emergency call.
Therefore, the member states must also upgrade and expand their emergency medical service chains accordingly.

We want this eCall emergency call system to be based on the EU's uniform emergency number 112, to be free of charge for users, to work throughout the EU, and to be compatible with the emergency call systems of neighboring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable, technology-neutral, open system architecture.
Other intelligent public transport services, such as real-time traffic information or availability of parking spaces, can also be offered through these systems at a later date.
In recognition of the automotive industry's outstanding achievements in providing private emergency call systems, these should retain their legitimacy alongside the public one-to-two-based eCall.
Users can also choose such a system based on comprehensive information.
This may also be associated with costs.
Use of data for workshops, insurance companies, towing services or other service providers.
A small village in Franconia is known for its good beer. This rhyme highlights a small problem we've created for ourselves today.

Because if this brewery or the beverage retailer is seven kilometers away from my home, I have no chance that they will continue to offer me their products in the future without having to buy a new tachograph, without new bureaucracy.

That is why I voted against this resolution today, because I believe that we should not impose too much on our small and medium-sized enterprises. There were many points that we managed to get in that were positive, thank God.
It was planned to only accept fifty kilometers within the radius of a regional provider.
That was completely absurd of the EU Commission.
So, a hundred kilometers is just barely feasible.
But what if it goes beyond that?
I think that's an exaggeration.
And one last point: as a representative of an employees' organization in the CSU, I must say that with this regulation, we are creating complete control over employees.
Why?
because, for example, the person who is responsible for construction or for beverages, for the breweries, offers his goods, and is monitored throughout the entire working day via GPS.
For these reasons, and also for data protection reasons, I consider what we have decided today to be highly questionable, and I would like to reiterate why I voted against it.
Thank you very much for this question.
why I am not waiting for this decision.
I waited for the approval of the European People's Party in the Legal Affairs Committee when we were still in the process of asking the necessary questions about legal certainty regarding ACTA.
And there was silence in the forest and refusal.
That's not what you wanted. It's now obvious that the ECJ is being used to delay things, that's clear.
that's why I mentioned the wide margin of interpretation.
Because you asked two questions, I have to answer both of them, unfortunately that's just the way it is.
because you can read into these broad formulations the monitoring of the internet, the auxiliary police, and ISPs, and interpret anything you want out of them.
And that means legal uncertainty. Legal uncertainty is not helpful for our economy either, ladies and gentlemen.
Mr Leichtfried, I would like to ask you: Are you in favour of discussing the modernisation of copyright at European level?
or are you completely against the rejection of any intellectual property?
And how do you envision the ECOMMERCE Directive being adapted to modern conditions in the future?
From your statement, I gather that you reject any debate on these issues and do not stand for intellectual property.
Is that correct or how do I see it?
Mr President, this is not about individual facts that we need to discuss, but about the fundamental question: How do we stand with democracy and with civil liberties?
And if we look at ACTA, we see that it is in a way symbolic of a lack of transparency, of a lack of democracy, of a violation of fundamental rights, because it was negotiated in secret.

and were brought about in an undemocratic manner, because the free use of the Internet simply would no longer be possible afterwards, and neither would the freedom to use generics to the same extent as before.
These are the reasons why millions of people have taken to the streets and have already voted against ACTA.
Yes, ACTA has been voted on in the streets, on the Internet, and in relation to the Committee on Petitions in many countries, not only within the EU, but also...
Even outside the EU. We must not ignore this vote. It is a vote of direct democracy by many citizens who elected us.
I can only tell you: put ACTA in the files, that would be decent.

Madam President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, as rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have completed two procedures under your presidency: the Financial Regulation, which provides a set of rules for the upcoming MFF period, and the OLAF procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation has been pending in the Council, and you have brought this process to a close based on the results of the Polish presidency.
I would therefore like to thank two truly dedicated financial officers who worked on these files, as well as Ambassador Trankommsen.
They will be missed. His efficiency as a negotiator will be missed.
They have truly earned themselves a reputation for looking after the financial interests of the European Union.
Thank you very much.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking here now as the representative of my group and would like to support the motion proposed by my colleague Mr Fjellner.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brain and our creativity.
This requires careful handling of the issue of intellectual property rights.
In order to clarify the outstanding issues, the European Commission has submitted this proposal, which it has presented to us, to the European Court of Justice for an opinion.
I believe that respect for the highest court of the European Union alone demands that we wait for this decision.
There is objectively no reason at all to make this decision today.
No one is prevented from voting against it once the Court has presented its decision and its opinion.
But the decision that will then be made will take place in a different consciousness, in a different awareness than today.
I don't mean to suggest that the wrong way drivers on the internet highway should determine our policy, which is why I ask you to support this motion. Thank you.
As always, when colleague Turmes speaks, he is very wise, and one would wish that what he says had much more influence on European politics.
I wanted to follow up on that.
Of course, these project bonds are a great idea, but only if they are sustainable and if the necessary political foundations are established.
We run the risk of using guarantees to hedge against risks that we do not have under political control.

Specifically, the energy transition in Germany would require a 3,800-kilometer network of transmission lines. So far, only 100 kilometers of these corresponding transmission lines have been built, partly due to resistance from citizens, including those who are very environmentally conscious.
We need to come up with something from politics.

One idea would be to create joint TEN corridors, which means not only combining high-speed rail lines and broadband networks, but perhaps also constructing transmission lines alongside the highways above them.
This does, however, require a much more comprehensive plan than has been provided so far, but I would like to at least suggest this at this point.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements in the European Union. However, I am also aware that a country's borders are always a very sensitive issue for our Member States and will always remain so.
I am aware that the problems between the member states regarding Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
There are various problems.
Ignoring does not make problems better and it does not solve them either.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic, and it would never occur to anyone here to want to close the border again just because we are having problems.
But I also ask the Commission for support in this area, not for restrictions and reprimands.
The veil ban has been implemented because we want to ensure security while allowing freedom of travel.

And if we carry out the veil investigation successfully, I assume that will also be the case at the borders with the Czech Republic, where one or another drug dealer is involved in many cases, not just a few.

If they are trying to find a way through in many cases, then I think it would be a good idea for the German Minister of the Interior and the Czech Minister to sit down together and solve the problems that exist at the border.
And the Commission should not regulate this, but rather act positively and supportively.

We want to put the populists in their place, but solve the real problems together. That is why I also ask the Council to work together with Parliament to find a solution so that we can successfully pass the Schengen dossiers, so that we have freedom of travel and at the same time ensure the security of citizens.
Madam President, the cases of disproportionate border controls that Parliament lists in its question also show why the Council actually wants to exclude Parliament from Schengen.
The Council wants to continue undermining freedom of travel without involving Parliament or without any form of parliamentary control, without any form of public scrutiny.
No wonder, then, that they prefer to pat themselves on the back in back rooms, away from uncomfortable questions.

It is no wonder that the German government wants to rule out any evaluation of internal borders altogether, without evaluation, and thus does not want to look at how much freedom of travel is being restricted.
However, Schengen does not belong to the governments, but to the people of Europe and therefore also to the European Parliament. Thank you very much.
Mr President, it is a special moment for me today and for my group to be able to welcome you here in your capacity as President of the Council of the European Union.
And we are also pleased that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person is at the helm of the EU whom we can count among our political family.
You are taking over the presidency at a time when the European Union is facing enormous challenges, and it is necessary to set the course for whether the European Union
whether the Union will actually have a future or whether it will prove itself to be a footnote in history, which in my view would be a historic defeat.

After the discussions we have had with you, with the representatives of your government, with the chairmen of the parliamentary groups and parties in your country, I know that you are counting on this
that you have excellently prepared for your presidency and that you are also aware of the significance of your task.
But you have also made it clear today that you want to deliberately draw the attention of those in power to the living conditions of people.
I can tell you this: after all that I have heard in recent years, this is the first time that a President of the European Union has done and announced exactly that, and said: This tone

I have long missed this in official speeches: the statement that this is about the people, it is about those who are not responsible for us being in this crisis, but who have to bear the greatest burdens.
It is difficult to implement this approach exactly.
I believe, however, that a great deal would already be achieved, and I am certain that you will do this, if you primarily win over the people with your presidency and the way you conduct it.
exercise their rights and contribute to ensuring that the Council and the European institutions are fully aware of this task.
We keep talking about the euro and its stability, about the necessity, which I also see, that it is important for the functioning of the European Union and for the Eurozone.
But that is an instrument.
There were political conditions for this, which were defined.

It can never be the goal of the European Union, in order for the euro to function, to accept that people in the European Union must go hungry, that health systems collapse, that municipal administrations have to cease their work.
Something has gone wrong here.
It is not what we can call the goal of the European Union.
I strongly support your demand that it must be about social cohesion, about solidarity between the individual member states, but also between the various population groups.
The European Union must not allow itself to be used repeatedly as an instrument or spokesperson for a specific segment of the population, nor should it present itself in this way.

And one last point I would like to address, of course, to emphasize that everything you have mentioned in your priorities is important to us and that we will support the points that go in this direction, as I have just defined them.
Please do something to ensure that people are no longer afraid.
Fear is the worst advisor for democracies.
I think that some decisions in recent weeks and months, particularly in the elections in Greece and the referendum votes in Ireland, were also driven by fear.
And if the rulers in the European Union contribute to people being afraid to make their own free decisions, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Best of luck with your work.
Dear colleagues, I believe that we have a very important responsibility here, also as co-rapporteurs.
The colleague will find it very important to work on this file quickly and reliably in the coming weeks and months.

The eyes of the world are currently on us and on the Council, waiting to see if we will take this step to overcome the banking crisis in Europe through a further step towards European integration, namely through a European banking union.
It should be noted that the Parliament demanded this with a broad majority two years ago.
We have conducted twenty-six trilogues.
We have taken a step in this direction, but unfortunately not as far as would have been necessary.
Additional billions in bills have been generated as a result.
It is good that the Council has now drawn the necessary conclusions and wants to take this step to further deepen the Eurozone.
It is commendable that the Commission has drawn up the proposals so quickly.
However, there are some difficulties associated with the Council's decision that the ECB should become the eurozone's supervisor.
This leads to unanimity in the Council and means that Parliament does not have codecision powers on this issue.
Based on the experience with the supervisory package, this is not acceptable.

That is why it is important that we work quickly here, but also that we negotiate this proposal on changes to the ECB together with the necessary changes to the existing supervisory regime as a package, thereby effectively establishing the principle of democratic participation by Parliament.
Democracies also face additional challenges.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has no responsibilities to date.

If it is now to be responsible for banking supervision, Parliament needs full budgetary rights, full control rights, the right to ask questions, the right to appoint, and I am sure that Parliament will fight for these rights by a broad majority.

We will thoroughly discuss the complicated issues in the coming weeks, including the internal market, consumer protection, and the balance between European power and financial responsibility. Thank you.
Mr President, by proposing to exclude developing countries from preferential market access, the Commission is attempting to push these countries into free trade agreements.
These free trade agreements, as the term economic partnerships suggests, are only concerned with the interests of the EU and not with the development interests of the partner countries.
This is completely contrary to the EU's goal of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments towards this objective.
Countries such as Cameroon, Ivory Coast, and Namibia would be severely affected by this restriction.
Regional integration projects such as those in Southeast Africa would collapse if Kenya were to enter into such an agreement.
South-South cooperation would be at an end.
We cannot advocate for free trade in the world and only mean that other countries should please buy our goods.
If the Commission really believes that trade can promote development, then it should not block it.
The development committee of this house has recommended rejecting the Commission's proposal.
We should support this in the plenary session.
Mr President, there are an enormous number of human rights problems in Central America, as well as in Peru and Colombia.
And we, as EU representatives, cannot simply close our eyes to this.
We will thoroughly examine the roadmap for human rights required by the EP in the case of Colombia and Peru, once it is drawn up.
It must have substance and be binding, and include initial results such as the conviction of criminals and the safe return of displaced persons to their country.
And of course it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.
We Greens believe it is right that the Trade Committee is demanding environmental and social standards in the proposed regulation on safeguard clauses, and not just tonnage restrictions for bananas.
The Trilogue must then confirm these, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
In fact, the EU must do much more to keep an eye on the situation on the ground and, above all, the impact on the local population.
That is why, as Greens, we demand a proper impact assessment before every negotiation, one that not only examines the economic consequences for the EU, but also the impact on human rights.
Mr Barroso, I made it clear in the first round what I wanted to focus on.
I am concerned with my group's expectation of the Commission to once again fulfill its responsibility within the relevant bodies, the Troika, in order to make it clear that we as

We, as a Commission, as a European institution, stand for the fact that people are not driven further into poverty, that working hours are not shortened, and that ecological and social standards are not undermined.
That is your task.

If we succeed in making this clear, we will also be sending a signal to the people who are protesting by the thousands and hundreds of thousands these days, who have taken to the streets, and with whom we, as a group, also express solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or in Barcelona.
I heard the news this morning that cancer patients in Greece are protesting and going on strike.
Where have we ended up, where people who are in deep social and personal distress can no longer receive any help and support because the health system has collapsed?
Here we must finally take action.
And I'll say one more thing: an approach that is in the minds of many responsible people is that the people in Greece and in other countries have been living beyond their means.
They must be punished for it today and must endure sanctions.
is unfit to strengthen a European community, a community of solidarity.
I am not accusing you of this, Mr. Barroso, but this is an approach that is prevalent in many countries and, unfortunately, is also repeatedly present in my own approach, for example.
Mr. Chairman, I admit, I made a mistake.
I would like to make a statement not on this report, but on the Moreira report on the agreement on immediate autonomous trade preferences for Pakistan.
I would then ask to be called up again.

Madam President. The new directive creates a foundation for handling books, newspapers, artworks, films, musical pieces, and TV productions that are protected by copyright, but for which the rightful owner cannot be identified or located.
Accordingly, books, films, photos, or other intellectual creations for which no rightful owner can be found should be made available to the public.
and thus a cultural treasure is unearthed.
For us on the Culture Committee, it was particularly important to emphasize the special significance of the diversity of the European Union's cultural heritage in this legislative initiative.

Our museums, libraries, publishers, and broadcasting organizations have countless unused works in their archives, and up until now, they have not been able to make these available simply because the rights holder is not known.
That changes with the directive.
In the future, it will enable the use of this cultural asset, provided that a thorough search is carried out prior to publication.
This is a very important point, so that it is not said lightly: We cannot find the rights holder.
Because a balance had to be found between the real existing rights of the creators of works and the public's need to be able to use such works where the legal situation is unclear.
A particular focus for us was also ensuring that both known and unknown rights holders continue to be fully protected.
And where the rights holders cannot be found, the draft makes it possible to use the digitization of orphan works.
Projects like Europeana and other major European digitization projects, as well as our museums, archives, educational institutions, and public broadcasting will flourish.
In the future, however, it must also be about opening up the orphaned works in the archives of private publishers to the public.
In my opinion, this draft of guidelines and the compromise that has now been reached is indeed a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
I believe that the cultural treasure that belongs to him holds enormous potential.
We should continue to work on this when revising the directive in two years. Thank you.
Mr President, Commissioner, President-in-Office of the Council, I would like us to have clarity in the 2013 proposal too.
We would like to see signals from the Council on how we can expand growth and competitiveness potential in Europe and, above all, how we can once again provide employment for young people.
Could you please tell us in which budget lines you promote youth employment and focus on entrepreneurship and small and medium-sized enterprises here?
We know that the ZIP program is the essential prerequisite for this. I only see cuts by the Council here.
or Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs or the Media Pluralism Programme, here there are only cuts.
Do you believe that we can overcome the crisis in Europe by making cuts in areas that guarantee growth and employment?
I heard that the Council is planning to propose a growth and employment package.
Where can this be found in this budget, which has been submitted by the Council?
Nordseewerke in Emmen had to file for insolvency last Wednesday because a guarantee from the Lower Saxony state government was not unexpectedly renewed.
This company, with seven hundred skilled jobs, is in the process of transforming from a shipyard to a supplier for offshore wind energy.

And now the idea is that this company can be saved through a bulk loan and that jobs can also be saved, because the seven hundred colleagues at SIAC and Nordseewerke have already had to accept significant cuts in wages.

Therefore, I ask the Commission to review this procedure benevolently, but also promptly, so that these seven jobs are not jeopardized, because these seven jobs are needed to organize the energy transition and to organize sustainable energy on the seas of Europe.
Please do not let the colleagues there suffer because of the state government's poor crisis management.
Dual-use goods often look harmless, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes, they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We undermine our foreign policy goals when we send surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes that can use them to control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile phone software from Nokia Siemens Networks that played into the hands of Iranian security forces in suppressing the Green protest movement.
Protesters were abducted en masse, arrested, tortured, and sentenced to death.
And that is just one example of many.
In addition, the Commission is said to be promoting these dubious dual-use goods through its catalogue of measures for innovative and competitive security industries.
The goal is to achieve a better utilization of synergies between security and defense technologies.
We risk literally selling out human rights, as well as our security interests, for the sake of a questionable industrial policy.
That is why I would like to ask you to approve the amendments from us, the Social Democrats, and ALDE.
I would like to ask Ms. Regner: What do you think trade unions could do to combat youth unemployment in Spain and Portugal, for example?
Demonstrations will be too few.
What active policy could the internal market implement here?
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that today's debate on MIFID touches on the core area of financial market regulation.
Those who have made it through this legislative period know that the issue at hand is to regulate the financial markets, not just to look at individual products, as we have done in the past.
I just want to mention a few key words.
We certainly didn't make things easy for each other last year.

We conducted a hearing in committee, we surveyed all stakeholders and all interested groups, and based on that, we developed a result through various processes, working documents, and similar things, which we will present to the plenary for a vote today and tomorrow.
I want to highlight a few points.
Topic number one: Market structure.

On the one hand, we must, of course, acknowledge that a great deal has happened in the financial markets in recent years, and it is in our interest as a parliament that all trading in financial instruments takes place within the rules of MiFID, which is why we are also subject to many conditions of a new category.

those who have agreed to the so-called Organized Trading Facilities, where only non-equities are to be traded, where proprietary trading is to be prohibited, and where appropriate execution at the discretion of the firm can take place with respect to execution, transaction, and customer interaction.
I believe that we are making an important contribution to ensuring that the entire range of OTC securities traded is conducted within the MIFID framework.
Another major issue that was not addressed in the last MIFID is so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.

Here too, our goal was to establish clear rules of the game, so that this area, which can be very dangerous and can also be used manipulatively, is subject to strict regulations with minimum holding periods.

with trading interruption options, with the ability to test algorithms, with the ability to view the supervisory structure of algorithms, with the introduction of a so-called tick size regime, a minimum price size, and through corresponding fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of waiting period markets.

I do believe that we have a special responsibility here to limit the speculative component in commodity futures markets in such a way that we do not contribute, through misguided regulations, to people in the third and fourth world being unable to buy food.
We have therefore adopted a two-pronged approach, with the aim of curbing speculation, but without harming the real economy.
We want to achieve this with position limits, with strict upper limits on the number of contracts or positions.
However, we also want to ensure that those who can prove that they really need a product are not suddenly engaging in speculative market intervention through a so-called position check system.
Another issue that concerns us greatly is the area of investor protection.
I would just like to point out here that we have chosen a very broad approach when it comes to ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
The aim here is to identify the needs of specific customer groups.
Not every small saver needs access to all highly complex documents.

It is about defining appropriate products for target groups, conducting product tests, telephone recordings, relevant consultations, disclosure obligations, but also - and I would like to briefly hint at this - implementing subsidiarity in the area of commissions.
Member States should have the opportunity to make appropriate adjustments in accordance with their structures.
I think we are on the right track.
When my time is up, I want to thank everyone who has contributed here.
I find it a shame that one only gets four minutes of speaking time for such a difficult dossier.
I would like to thank all my fellow Members who have contributed here, and the Commission for its very constructive role in recent weeks and months.

I hope that with a strong vote from the plenary tomorrow we will be able to enter into negotiations with the Council in order to conclude this important dossier as soon as possible. Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, first of all, thank you very much for the overall good cooperation on this report.
We have been able to further improve a Commission proposal at key points, which already took major steps in the right direction.
There will be more transparency in the area of market structures, and more comprehensive transparency, especially in the area of derivatives trading.

under the framework of MIFID. The decisions in the area of high-frequency trading in our compromise go much further than what the Commission had originally proposed and deserve the support of Parliament as a whole.
And even on the issues that have provoked widespread public criticism, the report points in the right direction.
In the area of commodities and food speculation, after major and difficult debates, it is now much stronger than the Commission's decisions, because position limits are established as binding there.
However, we still need further changes in this area to close any remaining gaps.
I also hope for further additions here through the plenary vote and eventually in the trialogue.
It is gratifying that Mr. Barnier has already signaled his support for the Parliament's more far-reaching proposal.
However, where the report has weaknesses is in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the ability to ban products, which is progress, but we still have no changes in the area of commission-driven advice.
The distribution of financial products is still not primarily oriented towards the interests of customers, but is heavily dominated by which product offers the most commissions.
Consumers have lost a lot of money, not only in Germany but throughout the EU.
Remember the open-ended real estate funds.
Unfortunately, for the citizens in France, Italy, Spain, and Germany, not much will change even after our compromise.
The basic principle will continue to be commission-oriented.
To refer to subsidiarity here is a bit too simplistic.
I would have liked to see stronger rules here.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. Yes, as the saying goes, all good things come to those who wait.
The report on type approval for category L vehicles has ultimately turned out to be a good report.
The work took longer overall than we all thought and, above all, than we had hoped, and there were far more pitfalls than we would have liked.
But at this point, I would like to once again express my heartfelt thanks to the rapporteur, Mr. van de Kamp, for the truly cooperative and excellent collaboration.
Together, we have still been able to achieve a lot in the negotiations with the member states.
As the rapporteur for my group, I recommend voting in favour of this report, even though it could have been much better.
And by better, my esteemed colleagues, I mean safer.
For us Social Democrats, the safety of vehicles and thus the safety of drivers, especially that of scooter and motorcycle riders, has been a priority from the very beginning.
The number of injured motorcyclists has remained constant for years.
In general, the number of accident fatalities in Europe is decreasing, but not in the case of motorcycle accidents.
Reducing the number of motorcyclists and scooter riders killed is indeed a matter close to my heart.
Fewer deaths on Europe's roads - that was and is my goal.
Every death is one too many.
